questions.text: At 36 weeks of gestation, a 28-year-old primigravida presents with reduced fetal movements. Cardiotocography indicates fetal heart rate deceleration due to uteroplacental insufficiency. On which day after fertilization is uteroplacental circulation established?
questions.solution:
Option C: 12th day

  • Uteroplacental circulation allows the maternal blood to flow into the intervillous space through decidual spiral arteries. It is essential to exchange oxygen and nutrients between maternal and fetal circulation, which helps the fetus grow. Oxygenated blood is transferred from maternal circulation to fetal circulation via uteroplacental circulation.
  • Uteroplacental circulation is established with the completion of the implantation process.
  • The blastocyst produces a slight protrusion into the lumen of the uterus.
  • The trophoblast is characterized by lacunar spaces in the syncytium that form an intercommunicating network.
  • At the same time, syncytiotrophoblast cells penetrate deeper into the stroma and erode the endothelial lining of the maternal capillaries (dilated and congested sinusoids).
  • The syncytial lacunae become continuous with the sinusoids, and maternal blood enters the lacunar system.
  • With more and more sinusoid invasion by the trophoblast, the lacunae eventually become continuous with the arterial and venous systems. Pressure differences between arterial and venous capillaries result in maternal blood flowing through the trophoblastic lacunar system to form the uteroplacental circulation.
  • This process is completed by day 12 after fertilization.

Option A: 8th day

  • Implantation is a week-long process starting from day 5 to day 12.
  • The uteroplacental circulation is established only after the completion of the implantation process.

Option B: 10th day

  • On day 10, the uteroplacental circulation is not completely developed and does not function properly.

Option D: 6th day

  • The uteroplacental circulation develops after implantation.
  • Implantation is immature on the 6th day, and the uteroplacental circulation has not fully developed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, one month postpartum, presents with lactation failure, fatigue, amenorrhea, and loss of pubic hair. Diagnosed with gland dysfunction syndrome, the gynecologist identifies derivatives of the germ layer from which the affected gland develops. Which structure listed below is not a derivative of the same germ layer?
questions.solution:
Option D: Arrector Pilorum

  • The patient has been diagnosed with Sheehan syndrome
  • This is a syndrome where pituitary becomes double its size, and the blood supply cannot compensate, leading to ischemia.
  • The patient presents with an inability to lactate, fatigue, and loss of pubic hair in the early postpartum period.
  • Anterior pituitary develops from oral ectoderm.
  • The lateral plate mesoderm has two components Dorsal Somatic lateral plate mesoderm and the Ventral visceral lateral plate mesoderm. Ventral Visceral Mesoderm derivatives are Visceral layers of Pleura, Peritoneum, and Pericardium. Visceral Muscles, Cardiac muscles, CV tube, Smooth muscles, Gut tube, and RespiratoryTube. 
  • Arrector Pilorum is a Smooth muscle in the skin. Derived from Mesenchyme

Option A: Epidermis

  • Surface ectoderm derivatives include
    • Epithelium and glands
    • Skin epithelium

Option B: Parotid gland

  • Surface ectoderm derivatives also include
    • Rathke's pouch (most of the pituitary gland)
    • Salivary glands
    • Parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands

Option C: Neurohypophysis

  • Neural plate ectoderm derivatives
    • Iris muscles: Sphincter and dilator pupillae
    • CNS
    • Neurohypophysis(posterior pituitary gland)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with burning in the mid-epigastric region, a sour taste in his mouth after meals, and a red tongue-like mucosa observed during endoscopy with biopsy showing columnar metaplasia. At what distance from the gastroesophageal junction is the Z line seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: 5 cm

  • The above given is a case of Barret's esophagus.
  • The mid-epigastric burning pain + sour taste is a classic symptom.
  • Z-Line:
    • Zig–zag line.
    • Squamous columnar junction at lower 2 cm of the esophagus.
    • The lower 2cm of the esophagus is lined by columnar epithelium.
    • Prone to metaplasia/ dysplasia.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.
  • The biopsy findings of columnar metaplasia and red mucosa on endoscopy confirm the diagnosis.

Option A: 2 cm

  • In normal individuals, the zig-zag line is located 2cm above the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.

Option B: 3 cm

  • Squamous columnar junction at lower 2 cm of the esophagus.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.

Option C: 4 cm

  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction, not 4cm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese male presents to the hospital with a complaint of not being able to feel the bitter and sweet taste for 1 month. He has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension for the last 6 months A medical consultant questioned a postgraduate resident that the taste pathway lies under which neural column?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Special Visceral Afferent:

  • A Special visceral afferent fiber (SVA) is an afferent fiber that develops together with the GIT tract.
  • They carry the senses of smell (olfaction) and taste (gustation).
  • The cranial nerves with SVA fibers are the olfactory, facial, glossopharyngeal, and vagus nerves.
  • The facial nerve receives taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, the glossopharyngeal from the posterior 1/3rd, and the vagus nerve from the epiglottis.
  • The sensory processes send projections to the medulla, from which they travel in the tractus solitarius, ending at the rostral nucleus solitarius.
  • Transmits information regarding smell and taste.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presented to the physician’s clinic with a sudden onset of neck pain radiating to the forearm for the past 1 day. He had been feeling a dull pain in the left upper back since playing golf two days earlier. The physician orders an MRI that reveals a cervical nerve root mass. Which of the following might be affected if the nerve root affected was C8?

choices.text: Adduction and Abduction of interossei muscles

questions.solution:
Option B: Flexors of wrist and fingers

C8 nerve root:

  • C8 nerve root supplies:
    • Pectoralis major (sternal head), Pectoralis minor, Triceps.
    • Flexor digitorum superficialis, pronator quadratus, flexor carpi ulnaris, extensor carpi ulnaris
    • Wrist and Finger flexors, e.g., Flexor pollicis longus and index Flexor digitorum profundus. Abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis.
    • Small muscles of the hand abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis.

Option A: Extensors of wrist and fingers

  • Wrist (and Finger) extensors are supplied by C6(7) through a radial nerve.

Option C: Adduction and Abduction of interossei muscles

  • Adduction and Abduction of digits (interossei muscles) and is supplied by T1

COption D: Supinators

  • C6 supplies supinators

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with a stab wound to the front of his left upper chest below the clavicle. The doctor suspects an injury to the anterior wall of the axilla. Which muscle is least likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Option C: Subscapularis

  • The posterior wall of the axilla is made up of the following muscles: 
    • Subscapularis
    • Latissimus dorsi
    • Teres major
  • These muscles cannot be injured in anterior wall injury. The anterior wall muscles are more likely to be injured.

Option A,B,D:

  • Pectoralis minor, pectoralis major, and subclavius are the muscles of the anterior wall of the axilla. Hence, there is a chance of its injury.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with recurrent dizziness and fainting episodes presents with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia. The clinician attributes the tachycardia to defective conduction through a structure at the apex of Koch's triangle. Which structure is not a boundary of Koch's triangle?
questions.solution:
Option B: Opening of inferior vena cava

  • Opening of the inferior vena cava do not form the boundary of Koch’s triangle
  • The boundaries of Koch's triangle include:
    • Tendon of Todaro
    • Opening of coronary sinus at the base
    • Septal cusp of the tricuspid valve (right atrioventricular valve)
    • AV node at the apex
  • The opening of the inferior vena cava is not one of the boundaries of Koch's triangle.
  • Radiofrequency ablation of Koch's triangle is one of the treatment methods used for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.

Option A: Tendon of Todaro

  • The tendon of Todaro forms the lateral wall of Koch's triangle.
  • It consists of subendocardial collagen fibers connected to the central fibrous body.
  • It is a component of the fibrous skeleton of the heart.
  • It also attaches to the septal cusps of the tricuspid valve.

Option C: Coronary sinus ostium

  • The coronary sinus ostium lies at the base of Koch's triangle.

Option D: Septal cusp of the tricuspid valve

  • The septal cusp of the tricuspid valve forms the inferomedial wall of Koch's triangle.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with intermittent right groin pain  that worsened over three months, accompanied by a limp and difficulty climbing stairs. Mild atrophy of right quadriceps and gluteal muscles is observed. On examination, standing on the right leg causes the left half of the pelvis to drop downward. Which muscle prevents tilting of the pelvis and trunk to the unsupported side while walking?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gluteus medius

  • This adolescent with right groin pain has a Trendelenburg sign,  drooping of the contralateral pelvis that occurs when standing on the affected leg.
  • The associated Trendelenburg gait, often described by patients as a limp, is caused by the compensatory shifting of the trunk to maintain balance during ambulation.
  • Both gluteus medius and minimus are responsible for the abduction of the hip and stabilization of the pelvis and contralateral hip joint.
  • The muscles gluteus medius and minimus are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.
  • The origin of these muscles: the outer surface of the ilium, and the insertion is at the anterior surface of the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • The main action of these muscles is abduction at the hip joint and tilting of the pelvis when walking to permit the opposite leg to clear the ground while stabilizing the contralateral pelvis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A,C,D

  • Gluteus maximus, Quadratus femoris and Pectineus are not responsible for Trendelenburg gait.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe thigh pain. A mass is palpated below the inguinal ligament, diagnosing a strangulated femoral hernia. What structure would be immediately lateral to the herniated structures?
questions.solution:
Option A: Femoral Vein

  • A femoral hernia is situated below the inguinal ligament and is present in females only as the femoral ring through which the abdominal contents protrude is larger in females
  • If the hernia gets strangulated, it can cause a lot of pain and has to be surgically treated
  • In the case of a femoral hernia, the contents of the abdomen are pressed through the femoral ring, which is directly lateral to the lacunar ligament and just medial to the femoral vein.
  • The femoral vein would be immediately lateral to the femoral hernia.

Option B: Femoral artery

  • The femoral artery is lateral to the femoral vein

Option C: Pectineus muscle

  • The pectineus muscle is situated inferiorly to the femoral ring

Option D: Femoral nerve

  • The femoral nerve is most lateral and is lateral to the femoral artery and vein

questions.text: A 67-year-old male visits the hospital with a complaint of fecal incontinence for the last 3 weeks. His history is significant for a lower back injury 1 month back. On examination, he is found to have a toneless external anal sphincter. Which of the following nerve roots innervate the external anal sphincter?
questions.solution:
Option A: S2, S3, S4

  • The external anal sphincter is supplied by the inferior anal nerve, a branch of the pudendal nerve, having root values S2, S3, and S4.
  • Injury to these nerve roots results in a toneless sphincter leading to fecal incontinence.

Option B: L5, S1

  • These nerve roots are most commonly compressed in the lower back leading to backache and leg pain.

Option C: S1, S2

  • These nerve roots are responsible for the ankle jerk.

Option D: L3, L4

  • These nerve roots are responsible for the knee jerk. They supply muscles of the lower leg.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant visits the clinic with complaints of frequent respiratory infections. On examination, a cleft palate, difficulty in breathing, cyanosis, and a significant delay in growth are found. A defect involving which of the following structures is associated with this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pharyngeal pouch 3 and 4:

  • This patient with frequent respiratory infections, cleft palate, difficulty in breathing, cyanosis and a significant delay in growth, most likely has DiGeorge syndrome.
  • DiGeorge syndrome is due to defects of pharyngeal pouches 3 and 4.
    • Pouch 3 & 4 compromised → Absent or poorly developed parathyroid → low PTH → Hypocalcemia.
    • Baby can die due to severe bacteremia or hypocalcemic tetany.
    • Most common cause of death in Digeorge syndrome- APseptalanomalies (cardiovascular defect)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pharyngeal pouch 1:

  • Pharyngeal pouch 1 develops into
    • Eustachian tube
    • Middle ear cavity
  • Any defect in the development/formation of the pouch will result in a defect in the Eustachian tube and middle ear cavity.

Option B - Pharyngeal pouch 2:

  • Pharyngeal pouch 2 forms endodermal epithelium for the palatine tonsil, with no role in developing the thymus.

Option D - Pharyngeal pouch 5:

  • Vestigial remnant of 5th pharyngeal pouch - ultimobranchial body
  • Ultimobranchial body fuses with 4th pouch and  receives neural crest cells which change into parafollicular C cells of thyroid. 
  • It has no role in the thymus development.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents with a sudden severe sore throat, left ear pain, voice change, and difficulty opening his mouth fully for the past 3 days. On examination, there is significant fluctuant erythematous swelling involving the left tonsil and drooling of saliva. Which nerve is responsible for the referred pain in the patient's ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Glossopharyngeal Nerve:

  • The above case scenario is typical of Quinsy, also known as a peritonsillar abscess, characterized by a fluctuant, erythematous unilateral swelling involving the tonsil.
  • Referred pain occurs when the different sensory pathways converge on the same level of the brainstem or spinal cord, resulting in the lack of distinction of the areas originally affected.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the posterior one-third of the tongue, palatine tonsils, oropharynx, middle ear mucosa, pharyngotympanic tube, and mastoid air cells. As the ear and the palatine tonsils share the same sensory nerve, the pain in cases of peritonsillar abscess can be referred to the ear. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Facial Nerve:

  • The facial nerve innervates the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, submandibular, and sublingual glands.
  • Hence, any inflammatory process in these structures can irritate the facial nerve and can cause referred otalgia.
  • Typical examples of referred otalgia via the facial nerve include
    • Dental infections
    • Herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion
    • Elongation of the styloid process and calcification of the stylohyoid ligament.

Option C - Trigeminal Nerve:

  • Trigeminal nerve supplies sensory innervation to the face, temporomandibular joint (TMJ), nasal cavity, and maxillary sinuses, and not within the oral cavity.
  • Referred otalgia may be caused by the trigeminal nerve in the following conditions:
    • TMJ Syndrome
    • Disorders of the mandible or lower dentition
    • Trigeminal neuralgia
    • Disorders of the maxillary sinus and the nasal cavity

Option D - Auriculotemporal Nerve:

  • The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of CN V3 and supplies parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland.
  • It causes referred otalgia only in the cases of parotid gland pathologies and post-parotidectomy.
  • It has no connection with the oral cavity or the otalgia referred from tonsillitis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes with his parents to the hospital with reports showing > +2 S.D height during childhood, and the parents complain that the child did not gain height after that. Which of the following conditions is not associated with tall stature during childhood but normal adult height?
questions.solution:
Option A: Osteogenesis Imperfecta

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) predisposes to short stature.
  • Short stature: Height of child < 3 percentile or < -2 SD of expected, according to age and sex of the child.
  • It is an Autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • Triad:
    • Recurrent fractures / Bony deformity
    • Blue sclera
    • Deafness
  • OI has Type-I collagen Defect
  • Dentinogenesis imperfecta (Dental problem)
  • Treatment: Bisphosphonates [Pamidronate]

Option B: Constitutional tall stature

  • This refers to individuals who are naturally taller than their peers due to their genetics, but they follow a normal growth pattern and eventually achieve a normal adult height. It is considered a normal variation in height.
  • Tall stature during childhood but normal adult height is seen in:
    • Constitutional tall stature
    • Precocious puberty
    • Soto’s syndrome

Option C: Precocious puberty

  • Precocious puberty is a condition in which a child's body starts maturing earlier than usual, including the development of secondary sexual characteristics and rapid growth. 
  • So, this condition is associated with tall stature during childhood with normal adult height.

Option D: Soto’s syndrome

  • It is also known as cerebral gigantism. It is an autosomal disorder. The characteristics of this disease include:
    • Long narrow face,
    • Small pointed chin and
    • The affected individual who is taller has an intellectual disability and behavioural problems.
    • Large head size
  • It is a rare genetic disorder caused by a mutation in nuclear receptor binding SET domain protein 1(NSD1) on chromosome 5.
  • It is characterized by excessive physical growth during the first few years of life.

questions.text: A 2-year-old female child is brought to the pediatric OPD by her mother, who was normal at birth having normal early development. However, she now presents with microcephaly, regression of acquired language and motor milestones, and abnormal stereotypic hand-wringing movements. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rett syndrome

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette is a classical case of Rett syndrome. The hallmark of the disease is the loss of motor skills and language and regression of the previously attained milestones of life (child starts to lose their skills).
  • Other features of Rett syndrome are:
    • X linked dominant inheritance
    • Gene involved - MECP2 gene
    • It is exclusively seen in females
    • Normal head circumference at birth and normal early development
    • Deceleration of head growth and acquired microcephaly
    • Loss of purposeful hand movements with the development of stereotypical hand-wringing movement

Option A: Angelman syndrome

  • It is a defect of gene silencing
  • It is characterized by seizures, ataxia, mental retardation, and inappropriate laughter (happy puppets)

Option C: Asperger syndrome

  • Asperger syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder within the family of autism spectrum disorder, characterized by significant difficulties in social interaction and non-verbal communication along with restrictive and repetitive behaviors or patterns, interests, and activities

Option D: Metachromatic leukodystrophy

  • Lysosomal storage disease
  • Inheritance is autosomal recessive and the gene is located on chromosome 22
  • Causes progressive demyelination of the central (white matter) and peripheral nervous system.
  • The characteristic metabolic defect is decreased urinary or leucocyte aryl sulphatase activity.

questions.text: A male infant is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. The mother states that the child sits with minimal support, attempts to attain a toy beyond reach, rolls over from a supine to a prone position, and does not have a pincer grasp. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. What is the developmental age of this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 6 months:

  • This is a case of a well-child examination in which the child sits with minimal support, attempts to attain a toy beyond reach, rolls over from a supine to a prone position, and does not have a pincer grasp.

  • Neck holding comes at three months.

  • Sitting with support is attained at six months. Sitting without support is attained at eight months. So, this baby is six months old.

Incorrect choices:

Option A- 3 months: Sitting with support is attained at six months, not 3 months.

Option C- 9 months: A 9-month-old child can sit without support and stand with support.

Option D- 12 months: A  12-month-old child can stand without support, walk with support and walk with one hand held.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to a pediatric hospital by his mother because of daily headaches, nausea, and vomiting for a month. On examination, papilledema is present. Further investigations were performed and they revealed a tumor with small, round, blue cells with Homer-Wright rosettes on histology. What is the most likely radiological finding of this tumor?

choices.text: Solid, homogeneous contrast enhancing lesion in posterior fossa causing obstruction to 4th ventricle & hydrocephalus.
Solid, homogeneous contrast-enhancing lesion in anterior fossa causing obstruction to 4th ventricle& hydrocephalus
Solid tumor with cystic areas containing fluid ± calcifications
Contrast enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Solid, homogeneous contrast enhancing lesion in posterior fossa causing obstruction to 4th ventricle & hydrocephalus:

  • This is the radiological finding of Medulloblastoma, which is the most common malignant brain tumor in children.
  • It is categorized as an embryonal neuroepithelial tumor of the cerebellum. 
  • Most common genetic abnormality: 17p deletion.
  • It occurs predominantly in males at a median age of 5-7 years. 
  • Patients present with signs and symptoms of increased ICP (i.e., headache, nausea, vomiting, mental status changes, hypertension) and cerebellar dysfunction (i.e., ataxia, poor balance, dysmetria). Fundoscopy may show papilledema. 
  • On histology, sheets of small round cells with Homer-Wright rosettes are noted. 
  • Investigations include CT and MRI of the brain and spine. CT brain may reveal a mass in the 4th ventricle.
  • Treatment modalities include surgical resection with chemotherapy and radiation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Solid, homogeneous contrast enhancing lesion in anterior fossa causing obstruction to 4rth ventricle & hydrocephalus:

  • Medulloblastoma is a cerebellar tumor arising from the posterior fossa, not anterior fossa.

Option C - Solid tumor with cystic areas containing fluid ± calcifications:

  • This is the radiological finding of Craniopharyngioma
  • It is histologically composed of cholesterol crystals and calcium deposits.

Option D - Contrast enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass:

  • This is the radiological finding of Pilocytic Astrocytoma.
  • On histology, bipolar neoplastic cells with hairy projections and Rosenthal fibers are seen.

questions.text: A newborn was brought to the OPD five days after delivery for a routine follow up. On examination, the baby is active. The pediatrician advised exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months and prescribed Vitamin D administration until 1 year. Which among the following is the correct dose of Vitamin D?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 400 IU/day:

  • All infants should receive 400 IU of vitamin D daily throughout the first year of life.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 300 IU/day

Option C - 500 IU/day

Option D - 600 IU/day

  • These are incorrect values of the dose of Vitamin D that is given during infancy

questions.text: A baby is born to a 30-year-old HIV-positive woman. The baby is healthy and has no abnormal physical or laboratory examination findings. The mother and baby are discharged with advice to start giving co-trimoxazole to the baby after 4 weeks. Which of the following statements is correct about the prophylaxis of co-trimoxazole in HIV patients?

choices.text: Can be administered in all asymptomatic HIV-infected children younger than 5 years of age, irrespective of CD4
Can be administered in all HIV-exposed infants after HIV infection is ruled out
Can be given to all HIV-infected infants less than 1 year ago, according to CD4 counts
Can be started in HIV-exposed infants before the diagnosis of HIV is confirmed

questions.solution:
Option D: Can be started in HIV-exposed infants before the diagnosis of HIV is confirmed

  • Co-trimoxazole is a combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim.
  • It is given as a prophylaxis against infections in confirmed and potential HIV patients.
  • Co-trimoxazole is started as prophylaxis against pneumocystis pneumoniae in babies born to HIV-positive mothers.
  • Prophylaxis can be started even before the confirmation of an HIV infection in the baby.
  • Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis is recommended for all HIV - exposed infants starting at 4-6 weeks of age (or at the first encounter with the health care system) and continued until HIV infection can be excluded.

Option A: Can be administered in all asymptomatic HIV-infected children younger than 5 years of age, irrespective of CD4

  • Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis is given to all HIV-positive children younger than 5 years, irrespective of CD4 count or clinical stage.
  • Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis can be discontinued for clinically stable children older than 5 years of age with a CD4 count of more than 350 cells/mm3.

Option B: Can be administered in all HIV-exposed infants after HIV infection is ruled out

  • HIV exposure occurs intranatally or through breastfeeding.
  • Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis reduces mortality and morbidity from opportunistic infections during infancy and early childhood.
  • Prophylaxis should be continued until HIV infection is excluded by antibody testing (beyond 18 months of age) or virological testing (beyond 18 months of age) at least 6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding.

Option C: Can be given to all HIV-infected infants less than 1 year ago, according to CD4 counts

  • All HIV-exposed or infected infants less than 1 year of age are given co-trimoxazole prophylaxis irrespective of CD4 counts and clinical symptoms.
  • Cotrimoxazole is recommended for HIV-exposed breastfeeding children of all ages.
  • After one year, prophylaxis treatment with co-trimoxazole is given only to symptomatic children or those with CD4 counts less than 350 cells/mm3.

questions.text: A newborn is examined in a renowned maternity and child institute. He was born to a 37-year-old healthy woman. A physical examination of the newborn shows that he has rocker-bottom feet, his fists are clenched with overlapping fingers, and his ears are low-set. There is a murmur on the auscultation of the chest. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Edward syndrome:

Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome) 

  • Important clinical features:
    • Rocker-bottom feet i.e., foot is convex from below like a rocking chair
    • Clenched fists with overlapping fingers, low-set ears
    • Cardiac anomalies
    • Kidney malformations
    • Microcephaly, prominent occiput
    • Mental retardation/Intellectual disability

Incorrect Options:

Option A  - Turner syndrome:

  • Basic defect: 45, XO
  • It is always seen in females
  • Most common congenital heart disease: Bicuspid aortic valve > Coarctation of aorta
  • Clinical features include:
  • Cardiac abnormalities, cystic hygroma, Cubitus valgus
  • Low posterior hairline, lymphedema of hands
  • Ovaries streak shaped/underdeveloped, Rudimentary nucleus
  • Webbed neck
  • Nipples are widely spaced on a shield shaped chest,
  • Normal intelligence

Option C - Patau syndrome:

It is more severe disorder than Trisomy 18

  •  Important clinical features: 
    • Cutis aplasia i.e., scalp defects
    • Microcephaly
    • Congenital heart diseases, Cleft lip, and palate
    • Holoprosencephaly i.e., cerebral hemispheres and ventricular system are not cleaved properly and are fused to each other to varying degree
    • Polydactyly (Post axial polydactyly more common)
    • Developmental delay, Intellectual disability

Option D - Noonan syndrome:

  • It has autosomal dominant inheritance
  • It is one of the disorders of the group called RASopathies,
  • RAS-MAPK pathway is involved
  • It presents with features like:
    • Short stature
    • Webbed neck
    • Cubitus valgus
    • Increased risk of congenital heart disease

questions.text: A 3-week-old baby boy is brought to the emergency room by the parents due to several episodes of vomiting, bloody stools, fever, and distended abdomen for four days. Since the time of birth, the baby has been formula-fed due to a lack of adequate breast milk in the mother. Which of the following is not included in the laboratory triad for the most likely diagnosis in this baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypokalemia

  • The laboratory triad that is present in necrotizing enterocolitis is:
    1. Metabolic acidosis
    2. Hyponatremia
    3. Persistent thrombocytopenia
  • Renal compensation to metabolic acidosis causes retention of H+ and K+ by the nephrons. This ultimately causes hyperkalemia, and not hypokalemia.
  • This 3-week-old formula-fed baby is experiencing symptoms suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis. 
  • It is commonly seen in preterm infants, but can infrequently occur in full-term infants with risk factors such as low birth weight, hypotension, and formula feeding.  
  • Hyperkalemia results from this condition due to renal compensation, not hypokalemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hyponatremia

Option C - Metabolic acidosis

Option D - Thrombocytopenia

  • These are included in the triad of blood investigation findings in NEC

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Ischemia tends to cause more rapid and severe tissue injury than hypoxia in the absence of ischemia

Reason (R): In ischemic tissues, aerobic metabolism is compromised, and anaerobic energy generation also stops.

Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not a correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A:

  • Ischemia is the most prevalent type of cell injury.
  • Restricted blood flow most commonly from arterial obstruction causes hypoxia in cells.
  • Reduced venous drainage can also be the cause.
  • In contrast to hypoxia, during which anaerobic glycolysis continues to produce energy, ischemia impairs the delivery of glycolysis substrates.
  • As a result, aerobic metabolism is limited in ischemic tissues, and anaerobic energy generation also ceases when glycolytic substrates are depleted, or glycolysis is blocked due to the accumulation of metabolites that would otherwise be washed away by circulating blood.
  • For this reason, ischemia tends to cause more rapid and severe cell and tissue injury than hypoxia alone.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following substances has the greatest affinity for neutrophils, in the context of chemotaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - C5a:

  • C5a has a very prominent affinity towards neutrophils. 
  • It is generated from the cleavage of complement protein C5 into C5a and C5b.
  • It is the most potent anaphylatoxin and acts as a powerful chemoattractant for neutrophils and monocytes, promoting their migration to sites of inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fucosyl transferase is chemotactic for neutrophils, but it is not as potent as C5a.

Option C and D are not chemotactic for neutrophils.

questions.text: What is the primary element involved in the process of healing by secondary intention in a large wound left to heal without sutures following the excision of a benign nevus from the lower back of a 39-year-old female under anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fibronectins:

  • Fibronectin is crucial in secondary intention healing due to:

    • Enhanced granulation tissue formation: Fibronectin promotes the formation of larger amounts of granulation tissue, facilitating wound closure in cases of extensive tissue deficits.
    • Scar maturation: Its involvement in scar formation ensures the transition from granulation tissue to a mature, avascular scar, essential for long-term wound stability and integrity.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D do not play a part in wound healing by secondary intention.

questions.text: A biopsy of a lung mass is done, and the histopathological finding is shown below. On immunohistochemical studies of this biopsy specimen, which of the following tumor markers would likely show strong expression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cytokeratin:

  •  The biopsy shows well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with prominent keratinization with keratin pearl formation, the most likely type of lung cancer is squamous cell carcinoma (SqCC), which tends to occur centrally and can cause bronchial obstruction.
  • The tumor marker most likely to show strong expression in squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is cytokeratin.
  • Cytokeratin is an intermediate filament.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alpha-fetoprotein:

  • Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and yolk sac carcinoma.

Option B - Calretinin:

  • Calretinin is a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C - Carcinoembryonic antigen:

  • Carcinoembryonic antigen is a marker for colonic carcinoma and many other malignancies (pancreatic Ca, lung Ca).

questions.text: Excisional biopsy of a 4cm breast lump shows malignant cells forming solid nests and gland-like structures surrounded by a dense collagenous stroma are found. A connective tissue stain (trichrome) of the biopsy is shown in the figure below. Which of the following terms best describes the blue areas observed in this specimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Desmoplastic change:

  • Desmoplasia refers to the growth of benign fibrous tissue secondary to tissue injury in cancer.
  • It is the proliferation of non-neoplastic fibrous connective tissue within a tumor.
  • Desmoplasia is a process seen in breast cancer, neuroendocrine tumors, lung cancer, and pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC)
  • The blue areas seen in the specimen are best described by desmoplasia.
  • A trichrome stain is a histological staining technique used to stain collagen fibers.
  • In desmoplastic tissue, the collagenous stroma appears prominently stained with blue dye, contrasting with the other tissue components. This results in a distinct visualization of the fibrous connective tissue surrounding the tumor cells.
  • The image presented above illustrates how the specimens are observed through H&E and trichrome staining..

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inflammatory change:

  • Inflammatory change refers to the presence of inflammation within the tissue.
  • This can involve the infiltration of immune cells, such as lymphocytes and macrophages, as part of the body's response to injury or infection.
  • Inflammatory changes can occur in tumors, but they are characterized by the presence of inflammatory cells rather than fibrous connective tissue proliferation.

Option B - Anaplastic change:

  • Anaplastic change refers to the loss of cellular differentiation and organization, leading to the development of more primitive and undifferentiated cells within a tumor.
  • This can result in features such as pleomorphism, increased nuclear size, and abnormal mitotic activity.
  • Anaplastic change is characteristic of malignant tumors and signifies dedifferentiation.

Option D - Dysplastic change:

  • Dysplastic change refers to the abnormal growth, differentiation, or development of cells within a tissue.
  • Dysplasia can range from mild to severe and is often considered a precursor to cancer.
  • It is characterized by cellular atypia, disordered growth patterns, and alterations in cell morphology.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a young female patient with iron deficiency anemia is shown below. Identify the cell labeled in this smear.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Basophil:

  • The labeled cell in this patient’s smear is a basophil.
  • Reactive basophilia is sometimes seen in iron deficiency anemia.
  • Basophils are the least common granulocytes in the blood, making up less than 1% of all circulating leukocytes.
  • Basophils stain purple with dense blue cytoplasmic granules overlaying and almost obscuring the nucleus.
  • They have a role in allergic reactions and helminth infestations.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient visits the clinic for a routine health visit. Her peripheral blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic red blood cells. Based on certain suspicion, her blood sample is taken and subjected to a test shown in the image below. Which of the following is associated with this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: The affected individual has HbF as the predominant hemoglobin.
It is a definitive test for the suspected condition.
Most individuals develop severe anemia as a clinical manifestation
Affected individuals rarely require blood transfusions.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Affected individuals rarely require blood transfusions:

  • The picture above shows the NESTROF test (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility test), which is done to screen for the thalassemia trait.
  • In the affected patient, the black line will not be visible as hemolysis doesn’t occur. [i.e. osmotic fragility is decreased].
  • Thalassemia trait is characterized by red cell indices and blood smear revealing a microcytic hypochromic picture with an elevated red cell count.
  • Transfusions are generally not required in these patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The affected individual has HbF as the predominant hemoglobin:

  • High-Pressure Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) shows HbA predominantly and elevated HbA2 levels (>3.5%) in individuals affected by the thalassemia trait.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B - It is a definitive test for the suspected condition:

  • NESTROF is a screening test, not definitive for confirmation of the diagnosis of thalassemia trait.
  • Hb electrophoresis can be helpful in further confirmation of the disorder.

Option C - Most individuals develop severe anemia as the clinical manifestation:

  • Individuals with beta thalassemia trait are usually asymptomatic and have normal or mildly reduced Hb levels.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect

questions.text: What's the most likely mutation in a 27-year-old male with recurrent abdominal pain, dark, tarry stools, and hyperpigmented macules on lips, buccal mucosa, and perioral region, with a family history of similar skin findings in the father, and a jejunal polyp on endoscopy with the following histological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  - Option- C) STK11 gene:

  • This image is a histology of the jejunal polyp and it shows arborizing bundles of smooth muscle surrounded by small intestinal glandular epithelium.

    The clinical presentation of recurrent abdominal pain, dark tarry stools, and the presence of hamartomatous polyps in the jejunum with characteristic histology, along with the mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation, is consistent with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

    Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is caused by mutations in the serine/threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene, also known as LKB1. This gene is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in STK11 are associated with the development of hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract, as well as mucocutaneous pigmentation.

Incorrect Options: 

The other options (A) TSC1 gene, (B) PTEN gene, and (D) APC gene are associated with different genetic syndromes:

  • TSC1 gene is associated with tuberous sclerosis.
  • PTEN gene is associated with Cowden syndrome.
  • APC gene is associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 69-year-old man experiencing nonspecific abdominal discomfort, maintaining a stable weight, and having a medical history of rheumatoid arthritis while undergoing medication, alongside the identification of the following gastric lesion during the endoscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chronic gastric peptic ulcer:

  • This patient with abdominal discomfort, a long-standing history of analgesic use for symptomatic relief, and the image showing characteristic radiating folds of gastric mucosa starting at the ulcer margins, most likely has a chronic gastric peptic ulcer.
  • The incidence of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is falling along with the reduced prevalence of H. pylori infection (owing to successful H. pylori eradication therapy).
  • However, PUD in patients older than 60 years has increased due to growing NSAID use (esp. selective COX-2 inhibitors).
  • The most common form of PUD occurs within the gastric antrum or duodenum as a result of chronic H. pylori-induced antral gastritis, which is associated with increased gastric acid secretion and decreased duodenal bicarbonate secretion.

Risk Factors for Peptic Ulcer Disease

• Helicobacter pylori infection

• Cigarette use (synergizes with H. pylori for gastric PUD)

• Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

• Illicit drugs, e.g., cocaine, that reduce mucosal blood flow

• NSAIDs (potentiated by corticosteroids)

• Alcoholic cirrhosis (primarily duodenal PUD)

• Psychological stress (can increase gastric acid secretion)

• Endocrine cell hyperplasia (can stimulate parietal cell growth and gastric acid secretion)

• Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (PUD of stomach, duodenum, and jejunum)

• Viral infection (CMV, herpes simplex virus)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gastric carcinoma:

  • It presents with features of:
    • Upper GI bleeding
    • Gastric outlet obstruction
    • Significant weight loss

Option C - Ménétrier disease:

  • It is characterized by foveolar hyperplasia leading to non-specific GIT-related symptoms and protein-losing gastropathy.
  • Endoscopy findings include prominent rugae involving the gastric fundus.

Option D - Gastroesophageal reflux disease:

  • It is characterized by epigastric discomfort, most commonly occurring in adults with a sedentary lifestyle.
  • It is most commonly reported after the intake of a meal in obese individuals.

questions.text: In a 55-year-old female nonsmoker with a peripherally located mass in the right lung and positive immunohistochemistry for CK 7 and TTF1, which of the following is correct regarding the underlying condition?

choices.text: Pathogenesis involves loss of function mutation of KRAS, ALK, and EGFR1
The tumor shows positive staining for MUC1 and NAPSIN A
Atypical Adenomatous Hyperplasia is not a predisposing factor

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The tumor shows positive staining for MUC1 and NAPSIN A:

  • The patient is likely suffering from adenocarcinoma carcinoma of the lung.
  • History: While adenocarcinoma can occur in smokers, it is more commonly seen in nonsmokers.
  • Clinical Presentation: symptoms like cough, hemoptysis, or weight loss, lung adenocarcinoma may present with locoregional spread symptoms, including superior vena cava obstruction, phrenic nerve palsy, Horner syndrome, compression of the brachial plexus, or pericardial effusion.

  • Adenocarcinoma

    EGFR, KRAS mutation

    ALK rearrangement

    Most common type in the world

    Peripheral

    No cavitation

    Migratory thrombophlebitis

    Trousseau phenomenon

    Clubbing

    Intermediate Prognosis

    TTF 1 +

    NAPSIN A +

    CK 7 +

    Surfactant apoprotein +

    Common in Non-smoker, women
  • Chest X-ray: Usually presents as a peripherally located mass.  
  • Histology: typically exhibits glandular structures. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pathogenesis Involves Loss of Function Mutation of KRAS, ALK, and EGFR1: This statement is not true. Adenocarcinoma of the lung, especially in nonsmokers, is often associated with gain of function mutations such as mutations in KRAS, ALK, and EGFR.

Option C - Atypical Adenomatous Hyperplasia is Not a Predisposing Factor: Atypical Adenomatous Hyperplasia (AAH) and Adenocarcinoma In Situ (AAH) are considered a precursor lesion to adenocarcinoma of the lung. Therefore, this statement is not true.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with advanced pancreatic cancer complained of chest pain for 30 minutes. ECG shows inferior wall myocardial infarction. Appropriate measures are taken, but the patient does not survive. Autopsy reveals sterile non-destructive vegetations along the mitral leaflet edges. Which of the following has a similar pathogenesis to this patient's vegetation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Trousseau syndrome:

  • The patient presents with an example of nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE).

  • The pathophysiology of NBTE is similar to that of Trousseau's syndrome (migratory thrombophlebitis).

  • Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) is the deposition of sterile thrombi on cardiac valves.

  • It is most likely seen with an underlying hypercoagulable state such as chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation, hyperoestrogenic states, and those associated with underlying malignancy especially mucinous adenocarcinoma of the pancreas and adenocarcinoma of the lungs (procoagulant effect of circulating mucin and tissue factor by tumours

  • It is also seen in conditions with general debility or wasting, known as marantic endocarditis.

  • The sterile valvular lesions of NBTE occur on previously normal valves and are non-destructive and small (1-5mm in diameter).

  • NBTE lesions give rise to emboli that can cause infarcts in the brain, heart, and other organs.

  • NBTE can also serve as a potential nidus for bacterial colonization and the consequent development of infective endocarditis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Hypercalcemia of malignancy:

  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy is a common finding in patients with advanced-stage cancers.

  • It presents with neuropsychiatric, gastrointestinal, renal, and bony abnormalities.

  • It does not form sterile vegetation in the valves.

Option B - Distant metastasis:

  • Cancer metastasis affects the pericardium and myocardium. It is less likely to affect cardiac valves.

  • Invasion of valves may rarely be seen in metastatic involvement

Option D - Raynaud’s phenomenon:

  • Raynaud’s phenomenon occurs due to spasm of small blood vessels in the fingers and toes.

  • It presents with skin colour changes, numbness, and sensations of pins and needles.

  • It has no link to valvular vegetations.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate diagnosis for a 54-year-old woman presenting with fever, weight loss, fatigue, petechiae, clubbing of fingers, and subsequent massive stroke leading to death, with an autopsy revealing the given mitral valve pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bacterial endocarditis:

  • In this case, the mitral valve has destructive vegetation that has been eroded through the free edges of the valve leaflets.

  • Vegetations in bacterial endocarditis form on the atrial side of the atrioventricular valves and the ventricular side of the semilunar valves, often at the occlusion points of the cusps or cusps.

  • They are made up of platelets, fibrin, cell debris, and masses of organisms.

  • The underlying valve tissue is damaged, so the leaflet is perforated and regurgitated.

  • The disease begins with nonspecific symptoms such as low fever, fatigue, anorexia, and weight loss.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Carcinoid heart disease:

  • Carcinoid heart disease affects the right side of the heart and causes tricuspid regurgitation and pulmonary stenosis.

  • It occurs in the advanced form of carcinoid syndrome.

  • This syndrome occurs due to a carcinoid tumor that secretes serotonin and other chemicals into the bloodstream.

  • It involves the right-sided heart walls and eventually leads to right heart failure.

Option C - Libman-Sacks endocarditis:

  • Libman-sacks endocarditis is a form of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis.

  • It most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves.

  • The vegetation has the following characteristics:

    • Small and firm

    • Friable

    • Tan masses

    • Broad base

  • The lesions are small (1 to 4 mm in diameter), single or multiple, sterile, pink vegetations with a warty (verrucous) appearance.

  • They may be located on the undersurfaces of the atrioventricular valves, on the valvular endocardium, on the chords, or on the mural endocardium of the atria or ventricles.

  • Vegetations are small, sterile, and firm and commonly affect the valve's lower surface.

  • Hypercoagulable states are the usual precursor to NBTE.

  • These include APLA syndrome, SLE, chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation, hyperestrogenic states, and those associated with underlying malignancy, particularly mucinous adenocarcinomas.

Option D - Mitral valve prolapse:

  • Mitral valve prolapse and congenital heart defects are the most common causes of bacterial endocarditis in adults today.

  • It is a type of valvular heart disease in which the valve between the left atrium and left ventricle does not close completely, resulting in a backward blood flow.

  • Mitral valve prolapse is the most common cause of mitral regurgitation.

  • It results in the following:

    • Arrhythmia

    • Heart murmur

    • Dyspnea

    • Palpitations

    • edema

questions.text: What is least likely to be seen in a 35-year-old female with recurrent urinary tract infections, flank pain, fever, frequent urination, leukocytosis, positive urine cultures for Escherichia coli, imaging findings of renal scarring and atrophy, and the given renal histology findings?

choices.text: It is not commonly associated with colonization of distal urethra and introitus.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C -

It is not commonly associated with colonization of the distal urethra and introitus:

  • The clinical presentation and histological findings described in the scenario are suggestive of chronic pyelonephritis.
  • This statement is incorrect. Recurrent urinary tract infections are often associated with colonization of the distal urethra and introitus, and they may contribute to the ascending infections that lead to chronic pyelonephritis.

  • The term "thyroidization of tubules" is often associated with chronic pyelonephritis, where the tubules take on a histological appearance resembling thyroid tissue (as in the middle section of the slide).
  • This finding is suggestive of long-standing chronic damage to the renal tubules, and it aligns with the clinical presentation of recurrent urinary tract infections, flank pain, and imaging showing scarring and atrophy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Interstitial fibrosis is observed:

 

  • Interstitial fibrosis is a characteristic feature of chronic pyelonephritis, and it is consistent with the scarring and atrophy of the renal parenchyma described in the scenario

Option B - Thyroidization of tubules is seen:

  • This is also a characteristic finding in chronic pyelonephritis, where the tubules exhibit eosinophilic-staining cells resembling thyroid tissue

Option D - Blunted calyces may be observed:

  • Blunted calyces are commonly observed in chronic pyelonephritis, and they result from scarring and atrophy of the renal parenchyma.

questions.text: What is the composition of the characteristic finding observed in the liver biopsy of a 45-year-old man with chronic alcohol abuse, presenting with abdominal pain, jaundice, malaise, elevated liver enzymes, centrilobular necrosis, and neutrophilic infiltration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D CK 8/18:

  • The clinical scenario indicates Alcoholic hepatitis, and the histology shows dense eosinophilic intracytoplasmic material which is consistent with Mallory- Denk bodies.

  • Mallory-Denk bodies are known to contain cytokeratins, specifically CK8 and CK18. These cytokeratins are part of the intermediate filament network in hepatocytes and are involved in the structural integrity of the cell. In the context of alcoholic hepatitis, the accumulation of Mallory-Denk bodies is a characteristic histopathological finding.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- CK 4:

  • Cytokeratin 4 is typically associated with stratified epithelia, such as the skin, and is not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies found in the liver in the context of alcoholic hepatitis

Option B CK 5/6:

  • Cytokeratin 5/6 is also not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies. CK5/6 is often used as a marker for basal cells in stratified epithelia and is not typically associated with hepatocytes.

Option C CK 7:

  • Cytokeratin 7 is commonly found in glandular epithelia, including the bile ducts, but it is not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies. In alcoholic hepatitis, the characteristic finding involves cytokeratins 8 and 18.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female patient came with complaints of throbbing sensation in her hands and feet. Her CBC showed a platelet count of 5.5L/cubic mm, but other parameters were normal. A peripheral smear reveals the feature shown below.



Which is the most likely mutation seen in her case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - MPL:

  • Presenting symptoms like erythromelalgia (throbbing sensation in her hands and feet), Lab findings of thrombocytosis, along with the peripheral smear showing staghorn megakaryocyte (shown in the image) is indicative of essential thrombocythemia.

  • Mutations in the MPL gene are commonly associated with essential thrombocythemia. The MPL gene encodes for the thrombopoietin receptor, and mutations can lead to increased platelet production.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. and the correct option is explained above.

questions.text: What disease presents a greater risk for a 52-year-old male exhibiting memory loss and personality changes, leading to death, as indicated by a brain biopsy given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Down's syndrome:

  • The image shows neurofibrillary tangles.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are abnormal aggregates of hyperphosphorylated Tau protein found inside nerve cells (neurons). These tangles are a hallmark neuropathological feature of Alzheimer's disease.
  • Individuals with Down's syndrome have an extra copy of chromosome 21, which carries the gene for amyloid precursor protein (APP). This genetic abnormality leads to an increased production of amyloid-beta peptide, a key component of amyloid plaques found in the brains of individuals with Alzheimer's disease. Consequently, individuals with Down's syndrome are at a higher risk of developing Alzheimer's pathology and symptoms at an earlier age compared to the general population. Therefore, Down's syndrome is a significant risk factor for Alzheimer's disease.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of Option C.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child is brought to the emergency department due to difficulty breathing and confusion for 2 hours. He worked on the farm alongside his father to spray pesticides onto plants. The clinician diagnoses him with cyanide poisoning. Which of the following citric acid cycle compounds is most likely to be depleted first due to cyanide poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – NAD:

  • Cyanide inhibits complex IV of the electron transport chain (ETC) by binding to Fe3+ of cytochrome oxidase.
  • This blocks ETC function, leading to NADH accumulation and subsequent depletion of NAD.
  • Consequently, the citric acid cycle (TCA) is affected due to the requirement of NAD for key enzymes like Isocitrate Dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, and Malate Dehydrogenase.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Aconitase:

  • Aconitase is a TCA cycle enzyme that catalyzes the isomerization of citrate to isocitrate without NADH.
  • Fluoroacetate and fluorocitrate are competitive inhibitors of aconitase.

Option C – Citrate:

  • Citrate is formed by condensing acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate in the first step of TCA by the enzyme citrate synthase.
  • It does not require any product of ETC.
  • Hence, its production will not be affected.

Option D - Acetyl-CoA:

  • Acetyl-CoA is the starting material for TCA cycle. Yet, it can also originate from amino acid breakdown and fatty acid oxidation, ensuring its production remains largely unaffected despite NAD availability.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of decreased vision in both eyes. His medical history is consistent with diabetes for the past 20 years.  A diagnosis of Snowflake cataract is made. Which of the following enzymes is responsible for this type of cataract?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sorbitol dehydrogenase:

  • In diabetics, excess glucose enters the eye cells freely.
  • Glucose is converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase.
  • Sorbitol accumulates because sorbitol dehydrogenase, which breaks it down, is absent in the eye.
  • Sorbitol is hygroscopic, causing cell swelling.
  • Excess sorbitol in the lens leads to snowflake cataract.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Galactose reductase:

  • This enzyme catalyzes the same reaction as aldose reductase but works specifically on galactose to produce galactitol.
  • Galactitol accumulation in the eyes causes oil-drop cataracts in galactosemic patients.

Option C - Fructose dehydrogenase:

  • This is a bacterial enzyme and is not present in humans.

Option D Alcohol dehydrogenase:

  • Alcohol dehydrogenase is a common enzyme involved in the metabolism and detoxification of any alcohol.
  • It catalyzes the oxidation of any alcohol to its aldehyde form.

questions.text: A 2-week-old child being breastfed is brought to the hospital by his mother because the infant appears restless. The mother also states that the infant has looked yellow since birth. On examination, the physician observed that the infant had icterus, hepatomegaly and bilateral cataracts. The blood examination shows normal blood glucose levels. What is the most probable reason for the child's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Galactosemia:

  • The child likely has Classical Galactosemia, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Galactose 1-uridyl transferase (GALT).
  • This results in the accumulation of galactose and galactose 1-phosphate in the body after ingesting galactose-containing foods.
  • Symptoms include
    • Hepatomegaly and jaundice due to liver dysfunction
    • Cataracts from galactitol accumulation in the lens
    • Hypoglycemia from excessive insulin secretion
    • CNS effects leading to lethargy or irritability
    • Hemolysis contributing to anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maple syrup urine disease:

  • MSUD, a metabolic disorder, causes the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine), leading to symptoms like sweet-smelling urine, neurological issues, poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and developmental delay.
  • However, persistent fever, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and cataracts are not usual symptoms of MSUD.

Option B - Hereditary fructose intolerance:

  • Hereditary fructose intolerance results from a deficiency in aldolase B enzyme, leading to an inability to metabolize fructose. Symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, hypoglycemia, liver dysfunction, and kidney problems.
  • Persistent fever, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and cataracts are not typical symptoms.

Option D - Glucose intolerance:

  • Glucose intolerance refers to the body's inability to properly regulate blood glucose levels. While it can lead to symptoms such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, and metabolic disturbances, the symptoms described in the case, including vomiting, persistent fever, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and cataracts, are not typical of glucose intolerance.

questions.text: Which of the following changes in kinetic parameters is associated with a non-competitive inhibitor?

choices.text: Increase in both Km and Vmax

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Decrease in Vmax:

Non-competitive inhibition

  • Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an enzyme's regulatory site, inducing a change in its configuration, preventing substrate binding and reaction.
  • Increasing substrate concentration does not overcome non-competitive inhibition, leading to decreased apparent Vmax.
  • However, Km remains unchanged, as non-competitive inhibitors do not interfere with substrate binding at the active site.
  • The effect is depicted graphically by a curve with unchanged Km but reduced Vmax.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Refer to the explanation of option A.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with vision problems, light-colored skin, learning disabilities, and a dipped chest bone. His father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 32. Ophthalmologic examination reveals downward and inward lens subluxation. What is the most likely amino acid accumulated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Homocysteine:

  • Homocystinuria is indicated by symptoms like lens subluxation, learning disabilities, skeletal abnormalities, and a family history of premature myocardial infarction.
  • It's caused by cystathionine β-synthase deficiency and features ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, and thromboembolic episodes.
  • Elevated homocysteine levels trigger endothelial injury, leading to atherosclerosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ornithine:

  • Elevated ornithine levels relate to urea cycle disorders, not atherosclerosis. Symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, and seizures.

Option B - Cysteine:

  • Cystinuria, resulting from cysteine metabolism defects, doesn't cause atherosclerotic plaque. It leads to recurrent cystine kidney stones.

Option D - Leucine:

  • Leucine metabolism disorders aren't linked to premature atherosclerosis. Symptoms include decreased appetite, lethargy, skin rash, and blood sugar fluctuations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for an annual examination. The patient feels well and has no complaints. Over the past year, she has been sexually active with three male partners and does not use barrier contraception. A speculum exam is performed, and a specimen is collected using a cytobrush. Pap smear testing reveals cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos. Which of the following best describes the normal histology of the region of the cervix from where this sample was obtained?

choices.text: Transition from squamous to columnar epithelial cells
Transition from squamous to cuboidal epithelial cell

questions.solution:
Option B: Transition from squamous to columnar epithelial cells

  • The cervical canal can be divided into three regions.
    • The endocervix is closer to the uterus and is lined by columnar epithelial cells.
    • The ectocervix is continuous with the vagina, and it is lined by mature squamous epithelial cells.
    • Where the squamous epithelium of the ectocervix and the columnar epithelium of the endocervix meet, there is a line called the squamocolumnar junction (also termed the transformation zone).

Option A: Cuboidal epithelial cells

  • Cuboidal epithelial cells are often found in organs with secretory, absorptive, or excretory functions.
  • These include the pancreas, kidneys, and parotid glands.
  • Simple cuboidal epithelium is also present on the outer surface of the ovaries.
  • However, cuboidal epithelial cells are not present in the cervix.

Option C: Squamous epithelial cells

  • Squamous epithelial cells are found in the ectocervix, which is continuous with the vagina.
  • A Pap smear is obtained at the transformation zone, where dysplasia most frequently happens.

Option D: Transition from squamous to cuboidal epithelial cell

  • Cuboidal epithelial cells are not present in the cervix.
  • Therefore, there would be no region in the cervix wherein squamous epithelial cells are replaced by cuboidal epithelial cells.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician by the mother for abdominal distention and leg pain. Physical examination discloses developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly. Further, fundoscopic examination reveals the presence of cherry-red spots in the macula. Histological examination of the bone marrow shows foamy macrophages. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Niemann Pick disease:

  • Inherited metabolic disorder, autosomal recessive.
  • Common in Ashkenazi Jewish population.
  • Due to deficiency of acid sphingomyelinase enzyme.
  • Characterized by sphingomyelin accumulation in organs.
  • Three types with varying severity.
  • Affected organs: liver, spleen, CNS, lungs.
  • Clinical features: intellectual disabilities, hepatosplenomegaly, cherry red spots, lymphadenopathy.
  • Foamy appearance of macrophages due to sphingomyelin accumulation.
  • No specific treatment, only symptom management.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sandhoff’s disease:

  • Rare genetic disorder causing destruction of nerve cells.
  • Deficiency of beta-hexosaminidase enzyme.
  • Accumulation of specific lipids in brain and organs.

Option B - Gaucher’s disease:

  • Accumulation of glucosylceramide.
  • Deficient enzyme: β-Glucocerebrosidase.

Option D - Fabry’s disease:

  • Excessive glycosphingolipid deposition in vascular endothelium.
  • Absence or deficiency of α-Galactosidase enzyme.
  • Accumulation of Globotriaosylceramide in multiple organs.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the dermatologist by her parents. She has many freckles on her face, neck, arms, and hands and her parents report that she is sensitive to sunlight. On examination, there is dry skin with hyperpigmentation and mild atrophy of the skin. Two lesions resembling basal cell carcinoma are observed on her face. Which processes are most likely to be defective in this patient?

choices.text: Removal of mismatched bases from the 3’ end of Okazaki fragments
Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA:

  • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a genetic disorder.
  • It is characterized by extreme sensitivity to sunlight.
  • Individuals with XP have a high risk of developing skin cancers at a young age.
  • This sensitivity arises from the inability to repair DNA damage caused by UV radiation.
  • UV light exposure induces the formation of pyrimidine dimers, specifically thymine dimers, in DNA.
  • Normal cells utilize the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway to recognize and remove these dimers from DNA.
  • In XP patients, mutations in genes involved in the NER pathway impair the removal of pyrimidine dimers.
  • Consequently, there is an accumulation of DNA damage.
  • This accumulation of DNA damage leads to the clinical manifestations observed in XP patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D are incorrect and the correct option has been explained above

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with large, prominent ears, an elongated face, large testicles, low muscle tone, and mild intellectual disability. An echocardiogram reveals mitral valve prolapse. Which of the following types of trinucleotide repeats occur in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CGG repeats:

The likely diagnosis in this patient is Fragile X syndrome.

  • Triple nucleotide repeat (CGG) occurs within the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome by insertion mutation.
  • Normally, there are 5 to 40 CCG repeats in the FMR1 gene, but in fragile X syndrome, CGG repeat occurs more than 200 times

​​​​​​​

  • CGG repeats cause hypermethylation of cytosine residues leading to decreased gene expression.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CAG repeat:

  • CAG repeat occurs in Huntington's disease.

Option B - CTG repeat:

  • CTG repeat occurs in myotonic dystrophy

Option D - GAA repeat:

  • GAA repeat occurs in Friedreich ataxia.
  • Athy
    • Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A 2-year-old male infant is presented to a pediatrician with dilated cardiomyopathy, hypothyroidism, inability to gain weight, dry skin, and failure to thrive. The patient is diagnosed with mineral deficiency, an essential component of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase. Based on the given information, which one of the following mineral supplements can help improve this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Selenium:

  • Found in seafood, meat, and nuts.
  • Exists as seleno-methionine (absorbed form) and seleno-cysteine (active, stored form).
  • Essential component of glutathione peroxidase enzyme.
  • Selenium-containing enzyme 5'-deiodinase converts T4 to T3 in the thyroid gland.
  • Deficiency: Keshan’s disease

Keshan's Disease:

  • Endemic cardiomyopathy in a region of China due to selenium-poor soil.
  • Symptoms include muscular weakness, inability to gain weight, hypothyroidism, hypertension, eczema, and increased risk of stroke and cancer.
  • Selenium toxicity (selenosis) causes emotional disturbance, diarrhea, hair loss, and garlic odor in breath due to dimethyl selenide.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chromium:

  • Found in meat, fruits, seafood, and vegetables.
  • Impacts insulin sensitivity.
  • Deficiency leads to glucose intolerance and insulin insensitivity.

Option C - Magnesium:

  • Part of bone matrix, prevents calcium accumulation.
  • Depletion treats hypokalemia and hypocalcemia; excess causes hypermagnesem

Option D - Copper:

  • Found in meat, fish, beans, and vegetables.
  • Absorbed by passive diffusion, transported as ceruloplasmin.
  • Used in melanin synthesis and coagulation; deficiency causes Menke's disease.

questions.text: In the early stages of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion, which of the following pathological contractions characterized by visible, jerky, and involuntary contraction is likely to be observed in a muscle supplied by the affected LMN?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Fasciculation:

  • Fasciculations are visible, jerky, and involuntary contractions of small groups of muscle fibers within a larger muscle. They are characteristic of lower motor neuron lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Tetanic contractions: Tetanic contraction refers to a sustained and continuous contraction of a muscle that occurs when the muscle is stimulated at a frequency that prevents it from fully relaxing between stimuli.

Option B – Fibrillation: Fibrillations are rapid, irregular contractions of individual muscle fibers that are not visible on the surface and can only be detected with electromyography. They are associated with the denervation of muscle fibers but are not visible or palpable like fasciculations.

Option D – Spasticity: It is a feature more commonly seen in upper motor neuron lesions and is characterized by increased muscle tone, exaggerated reflexes, and resistance to passive stretching of muscles.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of exertional dyspnea and a nonproductive cough. On chest X-ray, scar tissue is seen in the peripheries of the lungs. Notably, during exercise, while there is a minimal increase in arterial pressure, cardiac output can rise by as much as fivefold. How does the pulmonary circulation accommodate this substantial increase in cardiac output during physical exertion?

choices.text: Increase in the number of open capillaries
Sympathetically mediated greater distensibility of pulmonary vessels
A large amount of smooth muscle in pulmonary arterioles

questions.solution:
Correct option A: Increase the number of open capillaries

  • Based on the history of exertional dyspnea, nonproductive cough, and scar tissue on the x-ray, the most likely diagnosis is pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Pulmonary fibrosis is a pathological condition characterized by the scarring and subsequent thickening of lung tissue, leading to compromised lung function. This fibrotic process hinders the lungs' ability to effectively oxygenate the blood, resulting in decreased respiratory efficiency
  • During exercise, open capillaries increase in number, in order to enhance the capacity for blood flow through the pulmonary vessels to accommodate the elevated cardiac output (CO). This physiological adaptation ensures efficient gas exchange to meet the increased metabolic demands of the body.

  • But due to recruitment of more capillaries and dilatation of pulmonary capillaries (high compliance), resistance does not change significantly.
  • During exercise, cardiac output can increase several-fold without a greater mean pulmonary artery pressure increase.
  • Although the mean pulmonary artery pressure does enhance, the increase is only a few millimeters of mercury, even if the cardiac output has doubled or tripled.

Incorrect options

Option B: Sympathetically mediated greater distensibility of pulmonary vessels.

  • The physiological capacity of the pulmonary circulation to increase the distensibility of its vessels via sympathetic stimulation is not significantly observed.

Option C: A large amount of smooth muscle in pulmonary arterioles

  • A large amount of smooth muscle in pulmonary arterioles does help in maintaining resistance.

Option D: None of the above

  • Option A is correct, as discussed earlier in the explanation. So, this will be an incorrect option.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true of Ca2+ absorption from the intestines?

choices.text: Major absorption occurs in the ileum
It occurs mainly via the paracellular pathway
It is facilitated by phosphates in the diet

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It occurs by active transport:

  • Calcium absorption from the intestines occurs by active transport, primarily in the duodenum.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Major absorption occurs in the ileum:

  • Calcium ions are actively absorbed into the blood, especially from the duodenum.

Option B - It occurs mainly via the paracellular pathway:

  • Intestinal Ca2+ absorption is a crucial physiological process for maintaining bone mineralization and Ca2+ homeostasis. It occurs through the transcellular and paracellular pathways.

Option D - It is facilitated by phosphates in the diet:

  • PTH activates vitamin D, & the activated vitamin D, in turn, greatly enhances Ca2+ absorption.
  • Phosphates can form insoluble complexes with calcium in the intestine, reducing the amount of calcium available for absorption

questions.text: What is the positive wave in an ECG that appears after the wave representing atrial depolarization?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - R wave:

  • The R wave is the first positive deflection within the ECG after the P wave(atrial depolarization). It represents the depolarization of the ventricles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Q wave: The Q wave is the first negative deflection after the P wave. It indicates septal depolarization.

Option C - T wave: The T wave represents the repolarization of both the right and left ventricles.

Option D - S wave: The S wave represents depolarization of the base of ventricles.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency with complaints of lightheadedness and dizziness. ECG shows sinus bradycardia with sinus pause, followed by an escape rhythm. Which statement is true regarding the channels of the structure involved in the patient's pathology?

choices.text: It is a Na+-K+ ATPase pump
They are not responsible for diastolic depolarisation
It is responsible for spontaneous rhythm-producing tissue of the heart

questions.solution:
Correct option C: It is responsible for spontaneous rhythm-producing tissue of the heart

  • This is a case of sick sinus syndrome, which is caused due to sinus node dysfunction.
  • The HCN (hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated) channels are also known as the funny channel.
  • The funny current initially opposes the repolarization and then stops it.
  • After that, the funny current is responsible for spontaneous diastolic depolarization, which ultimately leads to the automaticity of the sinus node.
  • Since the funny current controls the rate of the sinus node activity, it determines the heart rate.
  • Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channel is a Na+ channel (permeable to both Na+ and K+ ions, with increased permeability to Na+), consisting of four either identical or non-identical subunits that are integrally embedded in the cell membranes of SA nodal cells to create an ion-conducting pore.
  • The more the hyperpolarization, the more the activation.
  • Equally permeable for Na+ & K+
  • After repolarization occurs by K+ exit in pacemaker cells, the next depolarization spontaneously reaches the threshold; a major part of this spontaneous depolarization is by Na+ funny channel.
  • HCN channels are encoded by four genes (HCN 1,2,3,4), with HCN4 widely expressed in the SA node.

Option A: It is a Na+-K+ ATPase pump

  • HCN channel is a Na+ channel (permeable to both Na+ and K+ ions, with increased permeability to Na+), consisting of four either identical or non-identical subunits that are integrally embedded in the cell membranes of SA nodal cells to create an ion-conducting pore. These HCN channels, or Hyperpolarization-activated Cyclic Nucleotide-gated channels generate funny currents which are integral to the function of the heart’s pacemaker cells. Na+-K+ ATPase channels are not directly responsible for the spontaneous depolarization and pacemaker potential.
