Option B: They are not responsible for diastolic depolarization

  • Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels pass a cationic current (Ih/If) that crucially contributes to the slow diastolic depolarization (SDD) of sinoatrial pacemaker cells that leads up to the threshold for generating an action potential. Hence, these channels are a key determinant of cardiac automaticity and the generation of the heartbeat.

Option D: They are voltage-independent channel

  • HCN channels are unique among vertebrate voltage-gated ion channels in that they have a reverse voltage dependence that leads to activation upon hyperpolarization. In addition, the voltage-dependent opening of these channels is directly regulated by the binding of cAMP.

questions.text: The following graph shows a relationship between lung volume and intrapleural pressure changes during inspiration & expiration. What is the most likely cause of different behaviour of inspiratory and expiratory curve?

choices.text: Difference in active and passive work during respiration
Difference in surfactant during inspiration and expiration
Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Difference in surfactant during inspiration and expiration

  • During inspiration, alveoli are small, and surfactant concentration is high, leading to decreased surface tension and increased lung compliance. This results in a steep increase in volume with a small change in pressure.
  • Conversely, during expiration, alveoli are large, the surfactant is scattered, and surface tension is comparatively higher, leading to decreased lung compliance. This results in a less significant change in volume despite a greater change in pressure, reflected by a straighter graph.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Difference in active and passive work during respiration:

  • Inspiration occurs due to the diaphragm mainly. However, expiration is a passive process. It does not affect the relationship between the change in volume and intrapleural pressure during inspiration and expiration.

Option C - Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration:

  • The difference in change in the volume of lungs between inspiration and expiration is due to the surfactant, not airway resistance.

Option D - Difference in intrapleural pressure:

  • Intrapleural pressure is negative all the time. During inspiration, it becomes more negative and causes expansion of the lungs. However, the graph following a different curve during inspiration and expiration is due to a change in surfactant.

questions.text: In a patient with left-sided renal artery stenosis, what change would be observed in renin levels within the systemic circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - High level of renin:

  • Left-sided renal artery stenosis leads to intrarenal hypotension, stimulating juxtaglomerular cells in the affected kidney to release renin into the circulation. This results in elevated systemic levels of renin, impacting both kidneys, including the right renal artery.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Low level of renin: Systemic levels of renin would be elevated due to the response from the affected kidney, resulting in increased renin levels rather than decreased levels.

Option C - Same level of renin as on the left renal vein: Renin levels in the systemic circulation would likely be higher than in the left renal vein due to the release of renin from the affected kidney.

Option D - None of the above: Since left-sided renal artery stenosis leads to increased renin secretion and elevated systemic levels of renin, this option is not correct.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is correctly represented by the graph below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Growth hormone:

  • GH secretion occurs in a pulsatile pattern, characterized by fluctuations in secretion levels.

Stimulate Growth Hormone Secretion

Inhibit Growth Hormone Secretion
  • Decreased blood glucose level
  • Decreased blood free fatty acid levels
  • Increased blood amino acid levels (arginine)
  • Starvation or fasting, protein deficiency
  • Trauma, stress, excitement
  • Exercise
  • Testosterone, estrogen
  • Deep sleep (stages 2 and 4 )
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone
  • Ghrelin
  • Increased blood glucose level
  • Increased blood free fatty acid levels
  • Aging
  • Obesity
  • Growth hormone inhibitory hormone (somatostatin)
  • Growth hormone (exogenous)
  • Insulin-like growth factors (somatomedins)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Insulin:

  • Insulin secretion peaks after meals, followed by a rapid decline in plasma levels. It circulates mainly in an unbound form with a short plasma half-life of about 6 minutes, cleared within 10 to 15 minutes.

Option B - Cortisol:

  • Cortisol secretion is stimulated by ACTH. Levels of corticotrophin-releasing hormone, ACTH, and cortisol are high in the early morning and low in the late evening. Plasma cortisol levels peak around 20 μg/dl before arising in the morning and decrease to about 5 μg/dl around midnight due to cyclical signals from the hypothalamus.

Option D - Thyroid:

  • TSH and TRH regulate thyroid hormone secretion. TSH levels are low during the day and increase at night, controlling the release of thyroid hormones. Thyroid hormone secretion doesn't follow a pulsatile pattern and doesn't acutely change in response to heavy exercise.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents to the clinic with a fever, headache, and sore throat. The physician diagnoses him with pharyngitis. During an infection, the set point of the hypothalamic temperature controller is set above normal. The diagram shows the effects of changing the set point of the hypothalamic temperature controller. Which of the following changes occurs at point W compared to point V?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Shivering and vasoconstriction:

  • When the set point of the hypothalamic temperature control center is raised above normal during an infection, it triggers shivering and vasoconstriction.
  • Shivering generates heat by increasing muscle activity, while vasoconstriction reduces blood flow to the skin, minimizing heat loss to the environment.
  • These responses help raise the body's temperature back to the elevated set point.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Shivering and vasodilation:

  • Vasodilation, which involves widening of blood vessels to increase blood flow to the skin and dissipate heat, is not characteristic of a response to an elevated set point during infection.

Option C - Sweating and vasodilation:

  • Sweating and vasodilation, which are mechanisms to dissipate heat, are not typically activated when the hypothalamic set point is increased during infection.

Option D - Sweating and vasoconstriction:

  • While vasoconstriction may occur to conserve heat, sweating, which helps dissipate heat, is not typically part of the response to an elevated set point during infection.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway?

choices.text: Cochlear nuclei-superior olive-inferior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus-medial geniculate-auditory cortex
Cochlear nuclei-inferior olive- inferior colliculus via the medial lemniscus-medial geniculate-auditory cortex
Cochlear nuclei-superior olive-superior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus-lateral geniculate-auditory cortex
Cochlear nuclei-inferior olive-inferior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus-lateral geniculate-auditory cortex

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cochlear nuclei-superior olive-inferior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus-medial geniculate-auditory cortex:

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway is as follows:

  • Cochlear nuclei
  • Superior olive
  • Inferior colliculus via the lateral lemniscus
  • Medial geniculate body
  • Auditory cortex
  • Electrical signals generated by the inner hair cells in the organ of Corti are conveyed to the medulla's dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei.
  • From cochlear nuclei, they reach the superior olivary nucleus of the pons and then to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain via the lateral lemniscus.
  • After other relays, the pathway leads to the medial geniculate bodies of the thalamus.
  • The thalamus then sends projections to the auditory cortex.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C, and D: All the sequences provided are inaccurate.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is in the CCU post-treatment for ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following antiplatelet drugs might cause unexpected results based on the CYP2C19 genotype of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Clopidogrel:

  • Platelet inhibitor, activated by CYP2C19
  • CYP2C19 gene involved in conversion to active form
  • Pharmacogenetic variations: poor metabolizers lead to inadequate platelet inhibition, extensive metabolizers may result in bleeding
  • Drugs requiring CYP2C19 metabolism: omeprazole, lansoprazole, amitriptyline, citalopram, phenytoin, diazepam, propranolol, and clopidogrel

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Prasugrel:

  • Antiplatelet, works like clopidogrel but doesn't need CYP2C19

Option C - Warfarin:

  • Anticoagulant, doesn't need CYP2C19

Option D - Omeprazole:

  • Proton pump inhibitor, needs CYP2C19 but not an antiplatele

questions.text: A group of pharmacists is experimenting with the effect of different types of antagonists. They take a drug and two antagonists for their experiment and draw a graph, as in the image given below, showing the log dose-response curve (DRC) of the drug alone (A) and in the presence of antagonists (B & C). Regarding their experiment, which type of antagonist do the curves B and C represent?

choices.text: B is competitive and C is noncompetitive antagonism
B is noncompetitive, and C is a competitive antagonism

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - B is competitive, and C is non-competitive antagonism:

Competitive and non-competitive antagonist:

  • Competitive antagonists compete to bind the same site on a receptor as an agonist.
  • Non-competitive antagonists bind to an allosteric site of the receptor, i.e., other than the active site.
  • In competitive antagonism, the DRC shifts towards the right, i.e., potency decreases, but efficacy remains the same.
  • On the other hand, in non-competitive antagonism, the curve becomes flat, i.e., potency remains the same, but efficacy decreases.
  • The DRC in the question shows that curve B is on the right side, representing an antagonist with the same efficacy as the drug (curve A) but is less potent.

  • So, curve B must represent a competitive antagonist.
  • On the other hand, curve C represents another antagonist with the same potency as the drug but less efficacy.
  • Therefore, curve C must represent a non-competitive antagonist.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: Refer to explanation given above

questions.text: A 68-year-old male complains of frequent urination, especially at night, and feeling of incomplete urination for three weeks. Suspected benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) prompts the doctor to order confirmatory tests. Considering this diagnosis, which medication would the doctor exercise caution in prescribing or avoid altogether?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Solifenacin:

  • This is a case of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in which the patient presents with complaints of increased frequency of urination, especially at night and sensation of incomplete urination for three weeks.
  • Solifenacin is an M3-type muscarinic receptor antagonist which is used to treat overactive bladder. It is contraindicated for use in patients with BPH as it can result in urinary retention.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tamsulosin:

  • Selective alpha-1a blocker, ideal for BPH with normal blood pressure.

Option B - Silodosin:

  • Another selective alpha-1a blocker, commonly used for BPH.

Option C - Dutasteride:

  • M3-type muscarinic receptor antagonist, contraindicated in BPH due to potential urinary retention.

questions.text: At 38, a woman in the ER reports mild chest pain, breathlessness, and syncope, alongside hypertension treated with amlodipine and a beta blocker for 6 months. Under job stress, her vitals reveal BP 100/60, HR 40 bpm, and temp 37.7º. Physical exam is normal. The doctor suspects beta blocker-induced severe bradycardia. What's least likely causing it?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pindolol:

  • Pindolol, with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA) alongside its beta receptor effects, poses the least risk of bradycardia.
  • Beta-blockers with ISA stimulate βadrenergic receptors while competitively inhibiting epinephrine and norepinephrine binding.
  • They're preferred in patients prone to bradycardia but less effective in angina due to β1 receptor stimulation.
  • Pindolol's partial sympathetic activity reduces bradycardia compared to other beta-blockers.
  • Beta blocker drugs with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (Mnemonic: COPAL):
    • C: Celiproplol, Carteolol
    • O: Oxprenolol
    • P: Pindolol
    • A: Acebutolol
    • L: Labetalol

Correct Options:

Option A - Metoprolol:

  • Cardio-selective beta1 blocker without ISA.
  • Decreases heart rate and cardiac output.
  • Can cause severe bradycardia due to complete antagonist activity against beta receptors.

Option B - Nadolol:

  • Non-selective beta blocker without ISA.
  • Decreases cardiac output and peripheral vasoconstriction.
  • Can cause severe bradycardia due to complete antagonist activity against beta receptors.

Option D - Atenolol:

  • Atenolol is a cardio-selective beta1 blocker without ISA, like metoprolol.
  • It acts with the same mechanism of action as metoprolol.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient presents to the emergency in an unconscious state. Clinical examination reveals that the patient's heartbeat is erratic, and there is a pulse deficit. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following anti-arrhythmic agents could be used for immediate effect in an emergency setting?
questions.solution:
Option B: Esmolol

  • Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker that can quickly reduce heart rate and blood pressure, effectively managing certain arrhythmias, such as supraventricular tachycardia or atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
  • Its rapid onset of action and short duration of effect makes it ideal for use in emergencies where prompt intervention is needed.
  • Esmolol can be administered intravenously, allowing for quick delivery and titration of the medication to achieve the desired effect.

Option A: Amiodarone

  • While amiodarone is a potent anti-arrhythmic agent, it has a slow onset of action. It is typically used for long-term management of arrhythmias rather than for immediate effect in emergencies.

Option C: Quinidine

  • Quinidine is effective for certain types of arrhythmias but is not commonly used in emergency settings due to its potential for serious side effects and the availability of safer alternatives.

Option D: Verapamil

  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can manage certain arrhythmias, but its onset of action may not be rapid enough for use in acute emergencies.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presents in the outpatient department with complaints of chest pain, palpitations, swelling in her legs, and shortness of breath. The vitals are in the normal range. On physical examination, there is bilateral pedal edema. She is a known case of dyslipidemia and is currently under the treatment of Gemfibrozil 300mg once a day. Keeping in mind the mechanism of action of this drug, it acts as a:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PPAR-α activator:

  • Used to treat high levels of lipids or triglycerides in the blood.
  • Mechanism: Binds and activates PPAR-α, leading to enhanced fatty acid oxidation, decreased triglyceride levels, and improved lipid metabolism.
  • Less preferred than statins; reduces triglycerides and increases good cholesterol.
  • Increases myopathy risk when used with statins.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HMG CoA inhibitor:

  • HMG CoA reductase inhibitors are also known as statins.
  • These are the most commonly used cholesterol-lowering drugs.

Option C - Inhibitor of cholesterol synthesis:

  • Statins inhibit HMG COA reductase.
  • Statins inhibit cholesterol synthesis.

Option D - Inhibitor of cholesterol absorption:

  • Ezetimibe inhibits intestinal cholesterol absorption.
  • It is used to treat high blood cholesterol along with dietary modifications

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents to the clinic with symptoms of palpitations and headache. On examination, his temperature was 37.6º C; BP was 172/96 mmHg, HR 96 bpm and RR 12/minute. On probing further, you understand that there's a history of insulin usage for diabetes, and the patient has had one or two hypoglycaemic episodes as he skipped meals. Which of the following medications, though they can reduce symptoms of the present illness, is better to be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Propranolol:

  • Symptoms suggest hypertension diagnosis.
  • Beta blockers reduce blood pressure and heart rate, often used in patients older than 45.
  • In insulin-dependent diabetics, beta blockers can mask hypoglycemia symptoms.
  • Complications in diabetic patients on non-selective β blockers include hypoglycemic unawareness, difficulty distinguishing hypoglycemia from normal sweating, and activation of β1 and β2 receptors leading to symptoms like tachycardia, tremors, sweating, and increased glucose levels.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Valsartan:

  • Angiotensin II receptor antagonist used in hypertension, diabetic neuropathy, and congestive heart failure.
  • Side effects: dizziness, increased BUN, blurred vision, back pain, syncope, allergic reaction, alopecia.
  • Contraindicated in diabetes.

 Option C - Verapamil:

  • Calcium channel blocker for hypertension, angina, and supraventricular tachycardia.
  • Side effects: gingival hyperplasia, headache, constipation, bradycardia, AV block, peripheral and pulmonary edema.
  • Causes hypoglycemia, not recommended for diabetics.

 Option D - Nifedipine:

  • Calcium channel blocker for hypertension and angina.
  • Side effects: peripheral edema, blurred vision, chest congestion, palpitations, sexual difficulties.
  • Not recommended in diabetic patients.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented to the emergency department with severe substernal chest pain radiating to his arm and back. ECG showed sinus rhythm with small Q waves in leads III and aVF, T-wave inversions in leads II and III, and aVF and ST depressions in V5 and V6. His vitals are normal. Cardiac markers are elevated. This patient can receive all of the following except?


	Ramipril
	Metoprolol
	Ticagrelor
	Streptokinase
	Enoxaparin
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Only 4:

The above scenario points towards diagnosing NSTEMI.

Initial Management:

  • Morphine for chest pain relief
  • Oxygen supplementation
  • Nitroglycerin for vasodilation
  • Aspirin as antiplatelet therapy; Ticagrelor as additional antiplatelet

Additional Therapy:

  • Metoprolol for beta-blockade
  • Statins for lipid management
  • Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), specifically Enoxaparin
  • ACE inhibitors or ARBs for blood pressure and heart function improvement

Note: Thrombolytics like Streptokinase are contraindicated in unstable angina and NSTEMI.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C:

  • All these drugs can be given as mentioned above

questions.text: What medications would you recommend for a 32-year-old pregnant woman experiencing frequent vomiting, fatigue, and nausea upon waking, with a reported decrease in food intake for over a week, as per her husband's observation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Doxylamine-Pyridoxine

  • All the symptoms above are the classic presentation of morning sickness in pregnant females. For mild- to moderate cases of vomiting in pregnant females.
  • Doxylamine, an H1 receptor antagonist, and pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) are combined to treat nausea and vomiting in pregnant women whose symptoms have not subsided despite dietary changes or other non-drug therapy.
  • Pyridoxine, a water-soluble vitamin, acts as a vital coenzyme in metabolizing amino acids, lipids, and carbohydrates.
  • The significant side effects of this drug (doxylamine) include drowsiness, dry mouth, light-headedness, and constipation.
  • For moderate cases, metoclopramide and ondansetron can be prescribed. But they are not essential for mild cases, as in this question.
  • It is highly safe for pregnancy as it qualifies for FDA pregnancy category A.

Option A: Ondansetron

  • Ondansetron belongs to the class of medications called serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonists.
  • While some studies suggest it may be safe, others have raised concerns about potential risks to the fetus, particularly when used in the first trimester.
  • Due to this uncertainty, ondansetron is typically reserved for cases where other treatments have failed or are contraindicated.

Option B: Metoclopramide

  • The drug metoclopramide belongs to the group of drugs known as prokinetic agents. It functions by accelerating how quickly food moves through the stomach and intestines.
  • However, it is generally considered less effective than doxylamine-pyridoxine for morning sickness and may cause side effects such as drowsiness, restlessness, and movement disorders.

Option D: Domperidone

  • Domperidone is a dopamine receptor antagonist.
  • While it can be effective for nausea and vomiting, including in pregnant women, its use is associated with a risk of cardiac side effects, particularly when used at high doses or for prolonged periods.

questions.text: In a 16-year-old boy with a history of eczema and recent respiratory symptoms, including cough, nasal congestion, and wheezing, which adverse effect is NOT typically associated with theophylline's blockade of adenosine receptors?
questions.solution:
Option D: GI discomfort

  • This patient is most likely suffering from bronchial asthma and receiving theophylline as part of his management. This drug exerts its bronchodilation effect by PDE inhibition and adenosine A1 antagonism. The side effects caused by these mechanisms of action are summarized below:
Nausea and vomiting PDE inhibition
Headache PDE inhibition
Gastric discomfort PDE inhibition
Diuresis Adenosine A1 antagonism
Arrhythmias PDE inhibition, A1 antagonism
Seizures Adenosine A1 antagonism
  • However, GI discomfort is not the side effect mediated by the blockade of the adenosine A1 antagonism.

Option A: Cardiac arrhythmias

  • These are the well-established side effects caused by the blockade of PDE inhibition and adenosine A1 antagonism.

Option B: Diuresis

  • The blockade of adenosine A1 antagonism causes diuresis.

Option C: Seizures

  • Adenosine A1 antagonism can lead to the development of seizures as a potential side effect.

questions.text: Which recently approved drug has shown significant reduction in disease progression in a 53-year-old male with diabetes and hypertension presenting with nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, altered taste sensation, blurred vision, diarrhea, extreme weakness, and worsening lower extremity edema, along with markedly elevated urea and creatinine levels?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dapagliflozin

  • This patient’s long-standing history of hypertension and diabetes and markedly abnormal laboratory findings (BUN, creatinine) and edema suggest CKD
  • Dapagliflozin, an SGLT-2 inhibitor, recently got approval for use in CKD patients, as it was found to reduce the progression of CKD in patients with and without diabetes.
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors are now being used as an additional drug for cases of Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, too.

Option A: Sotagliflozin

  • Sotagliflozin is an orally administered dual SGLT1/2 inhibitor used alongside insulin to improve glycemic control in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • While only SGLT2 inhibitors have emerged as a key disease-modifying therapy to prevent the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD).

Option B: Telmisartan

  • Telmisartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker
  • Telmisartan effectively and safely reduces proteinuria in chronic kidney disease patients
  • But it is not a recently approved drug for CKD

Option D: Valsartan

  • Valsartan is an Angiotensin receptor blocker
  • Suppression of the renin-angiotensin system is known to slow the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
  • But it is not a recently approved drug for CKD

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as a drug-eluting stent to prevent re-stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ridaforolimus:

  • Drug-eluting stents (DES) are commonly used in percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) procedures to prevent restenosis, which is the re-narrowing of the coronary artery after stent placement.
  • These stents are coated with medications that inhibit cell proliferation and reduce the risk of restenosis.
  • Ridaforolimus, however, is not commonly used as a drug in drug-eluting stents. While it also inhibits the mTOR pathway similar to sirolimus and everolimus, it is not widely used in clinical practice for this purpose.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following types of bipolar disorder is characterized by at least one episode of hypomania and one episode of depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Bipolar II Disorder

  • Bipolar II disorder is characterized by at least one episode of hypomania, which is a less severe form of mania, and one episode of depression.
  • In contrast, Bipolar I disorder is characterized by at least one episode of full-blown mania, which is more severe than hypomania, and one episode of depression.
  • Mixed episode bipolar disorder involves the presence of both manic and depressive symptoms at the same time.
  • Rapid cycling bipolar disorder refers to experiencing four or more mood episodes within a year.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Bipolar I disorder:

  • Bipolar I disorder is characterized by at least one episode of mania, which is a more severe and disruptive mood state than hypomania. A diagnosis of bipolar I does not require a history of major depression, but episodes of depression can occur alongside manic episodes.

Option C: Mixed episode bipolar disorder:

  • Mixed episode bipolar disorder involves the simultaneous occurrence of symptoms of both mania (or hypomania) and depression. This means that an individual experiences symptoms of elevated mood (mania or hypomania) and symptoms of depression at the same time, which can be distressing and challenging to manage.

Option D: Rapid cycling bipolar disorder:

  • Rapid cycling is not a distinct type of bipolar disorder but rather a specifier that can be applied to bipolar I or bipolar II. It is defined as having at least four or more mood episodes (mania, hypomania, depression, or mixed) within a year. Rapid cycling does not determine the presence of hypomania and depression; it relates to the frequency and pattern of mood episodes.

questions.text: Which of the following endocrine effects is associated with the use of lithium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Hypothyroidism

  • Lithium is known to increase the risk of hypothyroidism, especially in women and those with rapid cycling.
  • Regular monitoring of thyroid function is important in individuals taking lithium to detect and manage any potential thyroid-related issues.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hyperglycemia: Lithium is not typically associated with hyperglycemia or elevated blood sugar levels.

Option C - Hypernatremia: Lithium does not cause hypernatremia, which is characterized by high levels of sodium in the blood.

Option D - Hypercalcemia: Lithium does not cause hypercalcemia, which is characterized by high levels of calcium in the blood.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with alcohol withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, anxiety, and restlessness. The patient has a history of heavy alcohol use. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Benzodiazepines (BZDs)

  • Benzodiazepines are the treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal. They help alleviate withdrawal symptoms, reduce anxiety, and prevent seizures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs): SSRIs are not the first-line treatment for alcohol withdrawal. They are primarily used for treating depression and anxiety disorders.

Option C - Antipsychotics (such as Olanzapine): Antipsychotics may be used in cases of severe agitation and hallucinations that are not adequately controlled by benzodiazepines. However, they are not the first-line treatment for alcohol withdrawal.

Option D - Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine has shown effectiveness in treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms. It can be an alternative to benzodiazepines but is not the first-line treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is cortical dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Alzheimer's disease:

  • A cortical dementia involves the early involvement of the cortical structures in the brain, leading to cortical dysfunction and cognitive impairments. Among the given options, Alzheimer's disease is a well-known example of a cortical dementia. It is characterized by the progressive degeneration of cortical regions, resulting in memory loss, language difficulties, executive dysfunction, and other cognitive impairments.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Vascular dementia: Vascular dementia, on the other hand, is caused by impaired blood flow to the brain, often resulting from stroke or small vessel disease. It may also affect both cortical and subcortical regions of the brain.

Option C - Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease primarily affects the basal ganglia, which is a subcortical structure involved in motor control. It leads to motor symptoms, cognitive decline, and psychiatric disturbances.

Option D - Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's disease is also a subcortical dementia that affects the basal ganglia and presents with motor symptoms, such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Although Parkinson's disease can have associated cognitive impairments, it is primarily classified as a movement disorder rather than a primary cortical dementia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has been rescued from the bungalow of a businessman. She is a native of Thailand and had been allured with the promise of a job by a few men, who the police are on the lookout for. The forensic team has begun the physical examination of the victim. They found concentric teeth marks on the right forearm. What is the first procedure to be done with the finding?

choices.text: Keep scale for measuring below the mark and take photographs

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 2 swab technique for saliva collection:

  • Swabbing of saliva is the first step to be done to identify or exclude assailant .

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Keep scale for measuring below the mark and take photographs:

  • Photograph: Bite mark is photographed from different angles during the Bite mark investigation.
  • Bite marks can be matched for identification purposes with the dental profile of an accused.

Option C - Prepare cast using vinyl polysiloxane:

  • Impression of bite mark: Plastic substance (rubber or silicone based) or plaster of Paris is laid over the bite mark that hardens and produces permanent negative cast of the lesion.

Option D - Skin is removed and preserved:

  • Skin carrying the bite is removed and preserved in formalin during autopsy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old rape victim was brought to the hospital at 22 weeks of pregnancy. All of the following are correct statements regarding the case, except:

choices.text: Vaginal swab need not be taken
The fetus can be aborted after her consent
Examination can be done by a male doctor with a female attendant
Urine pregnancy test is not necessary

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The fetus can be aborted after her consent:

  • According to MTP act since the girl is not a major i.e < 18 years the fetus cannot be aborted after her consent.
  • The consent of a parent or guardian is necessary.

Incorrect Options:

Option A & D - Vaginal swab need not be taken & Urine pregnancy test is not necessary:

  • Since it is 22 weeks old pregnancy, so a vaginal swab is not necessary and urine pregnancy test is not necessary.

Option C - Examination can be done by a male doctor with a female attendant:

  • Examination can be done by a male doctor with a female attendant.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has consulted the doctor to abort her 10-week-old fetus. The woman allegedly has been harassed by her in-laws and is not willing to continue with the pregnancy. The husband and his parents are threatening the doctor to not proceed with the abortion. According to the MTP Act of 1971, consent from whom is needed by the doctor to legally proceed with the abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - pregnant women:

  • Only the consent of the pregnant woman is necessary.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Guardian:

  • For a minor or insane person – consent from a guardian is required.

Option C - Pregnant women and husband:

  • Only the consent of the pregnant woman is necessary.
  • Consent from the husband is not necessary.

Option D - Husband of the lady:

  • Consent from husband- not necessary.

questions.text: On examination of the lungs of the 10-year-old boy's body, the forensic doctor noticed large patches of hemorrhage. After identifying the location of the hemorrhage, the doctor documented the finding as Paltauf's hemorrhage. All of the following statements are true about it, except?

choices.text: Mostly seen in middle lobe of lungs
Due to rupture of alveolar walls

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mostly seen in middle lobe of lungs:

  • Paltauf’s hemorrhage is mostly seen in the lower lobes on the anterior surface and margins of the lungs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sign of drowning: Paltauf’s hemorrhage is seen in drowning.

Option B - Subpleural hemorrhage: Hemorrhages on the anterior surface of the lungs, present subpleurally with shining pale pink or bluish-red in colour, usually 1cm to 2cm in diameter are called Paltauf hemorrhages.

Option D - Due to rupture of alveolar walls: Paltauf’s hemorrhages are produced due to the rupture of alveolar walls as a result of increased pressure produced during forced expirations.

questions.text: A Person was admitted with diarrhoea, vomiting, low-grade fever, breathlessness, abdominal and lower limb pain and later became semiconscious, cyanotic, tachypneic, tachycardic and hypotensive and died. Autopsy finding revealed inflamed intestines with "rice-water" like contents and "red-velvety appearance" stomach mucosa. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Arsenic poisoning:

  • Gastrointestinal congestion is a feature of acute arsenic poisoning.
  • Focal hemorrhages giving rise to a flea-bitten appearance are said to be characteristic. Intestines may be inflamed and may contain “rice water” contents.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sulphuric acid poisoning:

  • Sulphuric acid poisoning: Colorless, Odorless, Non-fuming.
  • Signs & symptoms: Brown to black streak from the angle of mouth, Black tongue, Chalky white teeth, Black necrotic stomach or black charred stomach, Blotting paper stomach, Gastric perforation, The mind remains clear until death.
  • Fatal dose: 5-10 ml, Fatal period: 12-24 hours.
  • Sulphuric acid is the most common substance associated with vitriolage.

Option C - Phosphorus poisoning:

  • Signs and Symptoms of acute phosphorus poisoning:
    • Garlicky odor, Luminous vomit and stool because of the presence of phosphorus.
    • Fumes emanate from the stools (smoking or smoky stool syndrome). Acute poisoning causes liver cell necrosis, fatty liver, and acute yellow atrophy.
  • Chronic Phosphorus Poisoning (Phossy Jaw/Glass Jaw/Lucifer’s Jaw):
    • Due to inhalation of fumes over years. Toothache (earliest symptom) & swelling of the jaw; Loosening of the teeth & Necrosis of the lower jaw. Sequestration of bone in the mandible & multiple sinuses discharging foul-smelling pus.

Option D - Copper Poisoning 

  • Most of the time, poisoning is accidental.
    • Pain in the Throat, Abdomen
    • Ptyalism (increased salivation).
    • Vomiting (bluish green).
    • Hemolysis in RBC, liver, and kidney.
    • Chalcosis (Copper depositions in tissue)
      • o Chalcosis oculi (Copper deposition in eye)
      • o Defective copper metabolism is Wilson Disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of Schizophrenia presented to the emergency after ingesting a large glass of a pesticide diluted with water in response to auditory hallucinations. He was alert and in no apparent distress but had persistent hypotension and tachycardia that was unresponsive to fluid resuscitation. On day 2 a reddish rash appeared on palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum. It was documented as "Boiled lobster rash". This is seen in cases of poisoning with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Boric acid:

  • Boiled lobster’s rash is seen in poisoning with Boric acid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sulphuric acid:

  • Sulphuric acid is most commonly used for Vitriolage (Vitriol Throwing).
  • Discoloration and staining of the skin and clothing (brown or black in sulphuric acid, and yellow in nitric acid).
  • Poison having local action: Sulphuric acid.

Option C - Carbolic acid:

  • Poisoning by carbolic acid is known as carbolism.
  • Chronic poisoning (phenol/carbol marasmus): It is characterized by anorexia, progressive weight loss, excess production of saliva, headache, vertigo, dark urine, and pigmentation of skin and sclera (ochronosis). It was a common occupational disorder of physicians and their assistants during the mid 19th century when carbolic acid sprays were commonly used for antisepsis in operating rooms.
  • Gastric lavage can be done in poisoning with Carbolic acid.
  • Fatal dose: 1–2 gms of phenol, or 25–50 ml of household phenol. Fatal period: 3–4 hrs.

Option D - Formic acid:

  • Action: It has a corrosive action on (coagulation necrosis) on G.I. mucosa. It causes hemolysis leading to acute renal failure. ATP synthesis is diminished.
  • Fatal Dose: 50 to 200 ml.
  • Postmortem Appearances: Corrosion and blackening of gastric mucosa and pulmonary oedema.
  • Poisoning is suicidal or accidental.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is scheduled for surgery requiring muscle relaxation, and succinylcholine is considered for neuromuscular blockade. The anesthesia team is reviewing potential side effects. Among the listed options, which side effect is not typically associated with the administration of succinylcholine in the context of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bronchospasm:

  • Bronchospasm is not commonly associated with succinylcholine, it may primarily result from the administration of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that induces a higher release of histamine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyperkalemia:

  • Succinylcholine can induce a transient increase in serum potassium levels, particularly in patients with certain risk factors such as burns, denervation, and major trauma.

Option C - Increased IOP:

  • Succinylcholine administration may lead to a brief increase in intraocular pressure. This can be a concern in patients with glaucoma or eye injuries.

Option D - Fasciculation:

  • Fasciculation, or visible twitching of small muscle fibers, is a common and expected side effect of succinylcholine. It occurs because of the depolarizing action of succinylcholine on muscle fibers.
  • Fasciculation lasts for the initial 30 seconds.
  • Too many fasciculations involve vigorous muscle contraction, leading to post-operative myalgia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for intubation before surgery. During the airway assessment, the following findings were noted: Facial trauma, Inter Incisor Distance of >3 finger breadths, Thyroid To Mouth Distance of 2 finger breadths, Mallampati Class III, and the patient can touch his chest with his chin. What is the total Lemon Airway Classification score for this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the given findings:

  • Facial trauma = 1 point
  • Inter Incisor Distance > 3 finger breadths = 1 point
  • Thyroid To Mouth Distance of 2 finger breadths = 0 points
  • Mallampati Class III = 1 point
  • The patient can touch his chest with his chin = 1 point

In the Lemon Airway Classification system, points are assigned based on several parameters to predict the ease of intubation. The parameters are:

 

Look externally

facial trauma = 1 point

Evaluate 3-3-2 rule

Inter Incisor Distance > 3 finger breadths = 1 point, Thyroid To Mouth Distance < 3 finger breadths = 0 points

Mallampati Class

Class III = 1 point

Obstruction or lack thereof

ability to extend the neck = 0 points

Neck mobility

ability to touch the chest with the chin = 1 point

 

Adding these points together, the total Lemon Airway Classification score for this patient is:

Therefore, the correct answer is C. 4 points.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is operated on for intracranial bleeding. He was attached to mechanical ventilation using the given circuit. Which of the following circuits is shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mapleson A:

  • Mapleson A is also called the Magill circuit, the circuit of choice in adults for spontaneous ventilation.
  • It consists of a three-way T-tube connected to the fresh gas outlet, a reservoir bag, and a corrugated tube.
  • The other end of the reservoir tube is connected to the patient and a spring-loaded expiratory valve.
  • Corrugated rubber or plastic tubing: 110-130 cm in length.
  • Reservoir Bag at the Machine End.
  • A.P.L. valve at the patient end.
  • Tube volume > Tidal volume.
  • Advantages:
    • Best among all Mapleson systems for spontaneous ventilation.
    • Minimal wastage of gases during spontaneous ventilation
  • Disadvantages:
    • Not efficient for controlled ventilation.
    • Wastage of gases & operation theatre pollution.
    • The expiratory valve required produces slight resistance during expiration.
    • The expiratory valve (Heidbrink valve) is heavy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mapleson B:

  • The Mapleson B system features the fresh gas inlet near the patient, distal to the expiratory valve.
  • The expiratory valve opens when the pressure in the circuit increases and a mixture of alveolar gas and fresh gas is discharged.
  • During the next inspiration, a mixture of retained fresh gas and alveolar gas is inhaled.
  • Rebreathing is avoided with fresh gas flow rates of greater than twice the minute ventilation for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

Option C - Mapleson C:

  • This circuit is also known as Water's circuit.
  • It is similar in construction to Mapleson B, but the main tube is shorter. An FGF equal to twice the minute ventilation is required to prevent rebreathing.
  • CO2 builds up slowly with this circuit.
  • Mapleson B &C: To reduce rebreathing of alveolar gas, F.G. entry was shifted to near the patient.
  • This allows a complete mixing of F.G. and expired gas.
  • The result is that these systems are efficient neither during spontaneous nor during controlled ventilation.

Option D - Mapleson D:

  • Mapleson D (Bains circuit) is a circuit of choice for adults on controlled ventilation.
  • It consists of a fresh gas inlet nearer the patient end, a corrugated rubber tubing at one end, which is connected with an expiratory valve, and then a reservoir bag.
  • It is mainly used for assisted or controlled ventilation.
  • During controlled ventilation, there is little chance of rebreathing.
  • The FGF, which enters during the expiratory pause, accumulates in the patient end and is forced during inflation. In spontaneous breathing during inspiration, the patient will inhale the fresh gas & gas in a corrugated tube depending on FGF, T.V., length of expiratory pause & volume of the corrugated tube.
  • Rebreathing can be minimized by increasing FGF 2-3 times the MV.
  • For an adult, 15L/min FGF, which seems uneconomical, is required.
  • In some cases, 250 ml/kg/min is required to prevent rebreathing.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is admitted to the orthopedic ward after internal fixation of a comminuted fracture of the head of the radius. The patient complains of pain immediately after the operation. The anesthesiologist decides to give him a nerve block that involves injecting the anesthetic into the brachial plexus through the supraclavicular fossa. What is the most likely complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pneumothorax

  • The patient, in this case, is complaining of postoperative pain; supraclavicular brachial plexus block is an effective way to control postoperative pain after surgery of the arm from mid humerus to the hand, supraclavicular brachial plexus block consists of inserting the needle in the brachial plexus entering from the supraclavicular fossa, and the most common injury is pneumothorax due to the close proximation of pleura.
  • It is a regional anaesthetic technique used instead of general anaesthesia or for postoperative pain in operations involving the arm.
  • Complications include infection, bleeding, neuropathy and, most importantly, pneumothorax.

Option B: Horner syndrome

  • Horner syndrome is a complication of interscalene block.
  • The patient presents with complaints of miosis, ptosis, and anhydrosis.

Option C: Hypotension

  • Hypotension is a complication commonly associated with spinal anaesthesia.
  • It is caused by decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR) and cardiac output.

Option D: Systemic toxicity of local anesthetic

  • It is a complication associated with bier's block, a form of regional anaesthesia.
  • Bier's block is given by giving anaesthetic into the venous system while applying the tourniquet to prevent the systemic distribution of anaesthetic.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with intermittent dysphagia and a sensation of a mass in her chest while swallowing. A barium swallow study is performed and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Leiomyoma

  • Leiomyoma is a benign tumor originating from smooth muscle cells. The esophagus typically presents as a well-defined filling defect with a smooth contour on barium swallow studies. The characteristic crescent-shaped appearance is caused by the tumor pushing against the lumen of the esophagus during swallowing.
  • First image- The lesions (arrows) have a smooth surface (etched in white) and slightly obtuse borders characteristic of submucosal masses.
  • Middle image- En face view shows a smooth, rounded filling defect in the esophagus, with splitting of barium around the lesion. The esophagus appears widened at this level.
  • Last image- The tangential view reveals the characteristic features of a submucosal lesion. The outer margin of the leiomyoma is seen as a soft tissue shadow (arrows) abutting the lung.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Esophageal varices: Esophageal varices are dilated veins that occur in the setting of portal hypertension. They typically appear as tortuous, serpiginous structures on barium swallow studies rather than the smooth, well-defined filling defect seen in leiomyoma.

Option C - Esophageal carcinoma: Esophageal carcinoma refers to malignant tumors arising from the esophageal epithelium. It can cause irregular narrowing or strictures on barium swallow studies, but it does not typically present with the smooth, well-defined filling defect and crescent-shaped appearance seen in leiomyoma.

Option D - Zenker's diverticulum: Zenker's diverticulum is an outpouching of the esophageal mucosa in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It appears as a contrast-filled pouch during barium swallow studies. It is associated with the triad of Dysphagia, Regurgitation, and Halitosis.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant presents with persistent jaundice and hepatomegaly. A diagnostic workup is initiated, including an abdominal ultrasound. An ultrasound is performed:



Mark the incorrect statement regarding the condition:

choices.text: It is the most common cause of liver transplant in children
It’s management includes the Kasai procedure
It shows a triangular cord sign

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Enlarged gallbladder is seen

  • The triangular cord sign is observed in the image, indicating an echogenic area adjacent to the portal vein.
  • This finding suggests fibrosis, and when combined with the clinical presentation of the infant, it raises suspicion of biliary atresia.
  • In biliary atresia, the gallbladder is typically atretic and not dilated.

Biliary Atresia: 

  1. Cause: The exact cause is unknown, but it is believed to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
  2. Risk Factors: There is no specific known cause, but certain genetic and prenatal factors may contribute.
  3. Clinical Symptoms: Infants may present with jaundice, pale stools, dark urine, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive.
  4. Investigations:
    • Triangular cord sign on imaging (ultrasound).
    • Hepatobiliary scintigraphy (HIDA scan) can help evaluate biliary flow.
    • Liver biopsy may reveal fibrosis and bile duct proliferation.
  5. Management: Early intervention is crucial. The Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy) is performed to restore bile flow. If this is unsuccessful, liver transplantation may be considered.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is the most common cause of liver transplant in children:

  • Biliary atresia is the most common indication of liver transplant

Option B - It’s management includes the Kasai procedure:

  • Surgical management involves the Kasai procedure. It has a good outcome if done <8 weeks of age.

Option D - It shows a triangular cord sign:

  • The ultrasound given in the image shows a triangular cord sign. It is a feature of biliary atresia.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient presents with complaints of recurrent lower urinary tract symptoms, including painful urination, urgency, and frequent urination. He also reports intermittent fever and weight loss over the past few months. Urinalysis reveals pyuria and haematuria. Intravenous pyelography (IVP) and Cystoscopy are performed to evaluate the urinary tract and are given below.

 

Which of the following co-findings is most likely causing the patient's symptoms and matches the radiological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Tuberculosis (TB) of the Urinary Tract

  • Renal TB can lead to the moth-eaten calyx appearance on IVP due to caseating granulomas and the golf hole appearance at the ureteric orifice during cystoscopy due to ureteric involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Renal Cell Carcinoma: Renal cell carcinoma may present with hematuria and mass effect on IVP, Renal lesion with a heterogenous area of enhancement suggestive of renal cell carcinoma.

Option B - Renal Calculi: Renal calculi (kidney stones) can cause flank pain and hematuria.

Stag horn calculus

Option D - Polycystic Kidney Disease: Polycystic kidney disease is characterized by multiple renal cysts, and both kidneys are enlarged.

  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
  •  Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD).
  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

questions.text: The following appearance corresponds to what level of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 25 mm Hg:

  • The chest x-ray shows alveolar edema, which occurs when PCWP (pulmonary capillary wedge pressure) is more than 25 mmHg.
  • Normal PCWP range: 4-12 mmHg.
  • PCWP of 18-25 mmHg indicates interstitial edema, characterized by fluid accumulation in the interstitium.
  • PCWP exceeding 25 mmHg leads to alveolar edema, where fluid accumulates in the alveolar spaces. The characteristic appearance is called Bat wing appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of option B.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the pediatrician with skin lesions on the face. On examination, you observe several small, erythematous, and crusted lesions with honey-colored crusts on the child's cheeks and around the nose. The child's mother mentions that these lesions appeared after the child had been scratching an insect bite on the face.Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Topical antibiotic ointment:

  • The most appropriate management for the described condition is topical antibiotic ointment. The clinical presentation of small, erythematous, and crusted lesions with honey-colored crusts on the child's face is consistent with impetigo. Impetigo is a common bacterial skin infection, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. The primary treatment for impetigo involves the application of topical antibiotic ointment directly on the affected areas. This helps to eliminate the bacteria and promote healing of the lesions. Commonly used topical antibiotics for impetigo include mupirocin and fusidic acid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Topical corticosteroids: Topical corticosteroids are not appropriate for the management of impetigo. Corticosteroids are anti-inflammatory medications and are used to treat conditions involving inflammation, such as eczema or allergic reactions. However, impetigo is caused by a bacterial infection, and corticosteroids do not have any antibacterial properties.

Option B - Oral antifungal medication: Oral antifungal medications are used to treat fungal infections. However, impetigo is not a fungal infection but a bacterial infection. Therefore, oral antifungal medication is not the appropriate choice for the management of impetigo.

Option D - Oral antiviral medication: Oral antiviral medications are used to treat viral infections. However, impetigo is not caused by a virus but by bacteria. Therefore, oral antiviral medication is not indicated for the management of impetigo.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of scalp itching. He reports that many of his classmates are experiencing similar symptoms. On examination, gray scaly lesions are observed on the scalp, along with broken hair. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Tinea capitis:

  • The clinical presentation of gray scaly lesions on the scalp and broken hair is most consistent with tinea capitis, a fungal infection of the scalp. Tinea capitis commonly causes itching and can be transmitted among individuals, such as classmates in this case. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pediculosis capitis: Pediculosis capitis or lice infection, would typically show the presence of lice and nits (eggs) attached to the hair shafts. While lice infestation can cause itching, the gray scaly lesions and broken hair seen in this case are more indicative of tinea capitis.

Option C – Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically presents with well-defined, red, scaly plaques on the scalp, often accompanied by silvery scales. The gray scaly lesions and broken hair observed in this scenario are not consistent with the characteristic presentation of psoriasis.

Option D - Lichen planus: Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition that can affect the scalp, causing red, itchy, flat-topped papules or plaques. However, the gray scaly lesions and broken hair described in the clinical scenario are not typical findings of lichen planus.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for psoriasis during pregnancy due to its safety profile for both the mother and the developing fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Topical corticosteroids:

  • Psoriasis management during pregnancy requires careful consideration to ensure the safety of both the mother and the developing fetus. Topical corticosteroids are considered the treatment of choice for psoriasis during pregnancy. When applied topically, corticosteroids have limited systemic absorption, making them safer for use in pregnant women. They can help manage mild to moderate psoriasis symptoms without posing significant risks to the developing fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Methotrexate: 

  • Methotrexate is a systemic medication used to treat severe psoriasis. However, it is strictly contraindicated during pregnancy due to its potential to cause birth defects and harm to the developing fetus.

Option B- Cyclosporine: 

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive medication used for severe psoriasis. While it may be used under strict supervision in certain cases, it is generally avoided during pregnancy due to potential risks to the fetus.

Option D- Phototherapy (UVB): 

  • Phototherapy using ultraviolet B (UVB) light is another treatment option for psoriasis. However, during pregnancy, UVB phototherapy is generally avoided as there is limited data on its safety during this period.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a common pattern of depigmentation in vitiligo?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Universal pattern:

  • Universal pattern refers to widespread and symmetrical involvement of the entire body surface, which is rare in vitiligo. The more common patterns are acral (affecting the extremities), segmental (affecting a specific segment of the body), and focal (localized depigmented patches).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acral pattern:

  • Acral vitiligo is a common pattern of depigmentation in vitiligo. It affects the extremities, including the hands, feet, fingers, and toes. The involvement of the acral areas is often a characteristic feature of vitiligo.

Option B - Segmental pattern:

  • Segmental vitiligo is another common pattern of depigmentation in vitiligo. It is characterized by the presence of depigmented patches that are limited to one side or segment of the body, often following a dermatomal distribution.

Option C - Focal pattern 

  • Focal vitiligo is also a recognized pattern of depigmentation in vitiligo. It involves the presence of isolated and scattered depigmented patches on various areas of the body.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with severe ear pain, high fever, and bulging of the tympanic membrane in the right ear. Which antibiotic is commonly used in the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Amoxicillin:

  • The given clinical presentation is suggestive of stage of suppuration of acute suppurative otitis media.
  • In the treatment of ASOM, ampicillin or amoxicillin is the most commonly used antibiotic.
  • Amoxicillin is administered until the fever is reduced, tympanic membrane appears normal, and hearing is normal.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not the most commonly used antibiotic in the treatment for ASOM.

Option B - Azithromycin: Azithromycin is not the most commonly used antibiotic in the treatment for ASOM.

Option D - Doxycycline: is not the most commonly used antibiotic in the treatment for ASOM.

questions.text: What property of cholesteatoma contributes to its locally aggressive nature?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Enzyme degradation:

  • Cholesteatoma is a locally aggressive disease due to its ability to destroy bone through enzymatic activity, particularly enzymes like collagenase and acid phosphatase. This enzyme degradation leads to the erosion of surrounding structures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Pressure-driven spread: Cholesteatoma does not spread primarily through pressure but rather through the enzymatic degradation of tissues.

Option C- Fluid accumulation: While fluid accumulation may occur in cholesteatoma, it is not the primary property contributing to its locally aggressive nature.

Option D- Rapid cell proliferation: Cholesteatoma is characterized by the destructive action of enzymes, not rapid cell proliferation.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old patient presents with persistent ear discharge, pain behind the ear, and fever. On examination, the following can be noticed:



The symptoms have worsened. What is the most appropriate surgical intervention for managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Schwartz operation:

  • The clinical presentation of this patient is suggestive of acute mastoiditis. Schwartz operation, also known as Cortical mastoidectomy or intact canal wall mastoidectomy, is the most appropriate surgical intervention for managing this patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Radical Mastoidectomy: Radical Mastoidectomy is a more extensive procedure; therefore, it is not the most appropriate surgical intervention in this case.

Option B - Canal wall down mastoidectomy: Canal wall down mastoidectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing a portion of the posterior ear canal wall and mastoid bone. It is typically reserved for cases where more extensive disease or cholesteatoma is present.

Option D - Stapedectomy: Stapedectomy is a surgical procedure that addresses explicitly the stapes bone in the middle ear, and it is not indicated for the treatment of acute mastoiditis.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is consistent with the condition depicted in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Gelle’s test negative:

  • The given audiograph shows a dip at 2000Hz which is known as Cahart’s notch. It is seen in stapedial otosclerosis. Gelle's test is negative in otosclerosis, so when the pressure is increased or decreased in the external auditory canal and sound stimulation is given, the patient would not be able to appreciate the increase and decrease in the intensity of sound.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rinne's test positive: Rinne's test is negative in the case of stapedial otosclerosis.

Option B - Prolonged absolute bone conduction: Absolute bone conduction is usually normal in stapedial otosclerosis.

Option C - AD graph on tympanometry: The presence of a Type A tympanogram is indicative of stapedial otosclerosis.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent nasal congestion, purulent nasal discharge, headache, and swelling on his forehead. On examination:



Which condition is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pott's puffy tumor:

  • In this case, the patient presents with symptoms suggestive of frontal sinusitis, including congestion, purulent nasal discharge, headache, and swelling on the forehead. The swelling on the forehead corresponds to the Pott's puffy tumor which is characterized by subperiosteal cellulitis or abscess of the frontal bone associated
    with frontal osteomyelitis, often secondary to sinusitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mucocele: A Mucocoele of the frontal sinus is associated with the eye being displaced forward, downward, laterally, proptosis, and cystic swelling, which is non-tender and exhibits eggshell cracking. Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of frontal sinus into the middle meatus.

Option C - Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not associated with the given clinical presentation.

Option D - Orbital cellulitis: Orbital cellulitis is not associated with the given clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman from Kangra presents with a gradual onset of nasal obstruction and difficulty breathing. On examination, you notice a narrowing of the nares and nasopharynx. The patient reports a history of foul-smelling, purulent nasal discharge, and crust formation over several months. Which deformity is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Tapir nose:

  • In a patient from Kangra (North India) presenting with foul-smelling, purulent nasal discharge, crust formation, and narrowing of the nares and nasopharynx, the associated deformity is likely to be a "Tapir nose." This deformity occurs in the cicatrizing stage of Rhinoscleroma, leading to fibrosis and narrowing of the nasal structures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Hebra nose: In the granulomatous stage of Rhinoscleroma, a woody hard nodule results in deformity of the nose, known as a Hebra nose. It is not associated with narrowing of nose.

Option C- Crooked nose: Crooked nose is not seen in Rhinoscleroma.

Option D- Saddle nose: Saddle nose is not seen in Rhinoscleroma.

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding quinsy:

choices.text: Collection of pus between the tonsil capsule and inferior constrictor muscle.
More common in children due to the superficial nature of tonsillar crypts
Hot potato voice is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hot potato voice is a characteristic feature:

  • Hot potato voice, or muffled voice, is a characteristic clinical finding in patients with quinsy (peritonsillar abscess). Other clinical findings include:
    • Throat pain, usually unilateral
    • Odynophagia
    • Referred otalgia (by glossopharyngeal nerve)
    • Trismus

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Collection of pus between the tonsil capsule and inferior constrictor muscle: The peritonsillar abscess forms between the tonsil capsule and the superior constrictor muscle, not the inferior constrictor muscle.

Option B - More common in children due to the superficial nature of tonsillar crypts: Peritonsillar abscesses are actually more common in adults due to the deeper nature of tonsillar crypts, not in children.

Option C - It refers to intra-tonsillar abscess: Quinsy refers to a peritonsillar abscess, which is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space, not an intra-tonsillar abscess.

questions.text: What is the characteristic nature of stridor seen in the condition depicted in the image of laryngoscopy given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Stridor in supine position:

  • The given image shows omega-shaped epiglottis, which is a feature of laryngomalacia. In laryngomalacia, the characteristic nature of stridor is that it worsens when the infant is in the supine position. This exacerbation occurs because when the child is lying on their back, the epiglottis falls backward and covers the laryngeal inlet, leading to increased airway obstruction and thus worsening of the stridor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Stridor in prone position: Laryngomalacia typically presents with stridor worsening in the supine position, not in the prone position.

Option B- Stridor during expiration: Laryngomalacia typically manifests with inspiratory stridor, not expiratory stridor.

Option C- Stridor diminishes while crying: Crying exacerbates the stridor in laryngomalacia due to the negative intrathoracic pressure created during crying, which pulls the epiglottis further inward, causing increased airway obstruction and worsening of the stridor.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented to the physician with complaints of severe pain around the eyes after a fall on a symmetrical surface 2 hours ago. He has no history of any chronic illness. He is otherwise vitally stable. On examination of the patient, there is enophthalmos, diplopia on the upward gaze and loss of sensitivity over the cheek. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient’s current pathology?

choices.text: Zygomatic bone is most likely injured

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It is a blow-out fracture:

  • A blow out fracture refers to a fracture of the bones surrounding the orbit (eye socket) resulting from a sudden increase in intraorbital pressure, typically due to a direct blow to the area. In this case, the patient's history of a fall on a symmetrical surface, severe eye pain, enophthalmos (sunken appearance of the eyeball), diplopia on upward gaze, and loss of sensitivity over the cheek are suggestive of a blowout fracture.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maxillary fracture: Maxillary fractures typically involve the maxillary bone, which forms the upper jaw. They can occur due to trauma but are unlikely to cause enophthalmos and diplopia on upward gaze.

Option C - Zygomatic bone is most likely injured: The zygomatic bone, also known as the cheekbone, can be injured in trauma. However, it is less likely to cause enophthalmos and diplopia on upward gaze, which are more indicative of a blow-out fracture.

Option D - Frontal bone fracture: Fractures of the frontal bone, which forms the forehead, can occur due to trauma. However, they are unlikely to cause enophthalmos and diplopia on upward gaze, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient who recently underwent cataract surgery presents with symptoms of recurrent episodes of increased intraocular pressure. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist suspects UGH syndrome. Which type of IOL is most likely associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ACIOL:

  • UGH syndrome (Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema) can occur as a complication of ACIOL (Anterior Chamber Intraocular Lens). The ACIOL can block the angle, leading to increased intraocular pressure, glaucoma, and bleeding into the anterior chamber (hyphema), along with uveitis, resulting in UGH syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - PCIOL (Posterior Chamber Intraocular Lens): PCIOLs are positioned in the posterior chamber of the eye, away from the angle and iris. They are less likely to cause angle blockage and subsequent glaucoma or hyphema.

Option C - Toric IOL: Toric IOLs are specialized lenses used to correct astigmatism. They are not directly associated with UGH syndrome.

Option D - Multifocal IOL: Multifocal IOLs are designed to provide vision correction at multiple distances, and they are typically placed in the posterior chamber.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presents with pain, redness, and blurred vision in her right eye. The ophthalmologist observes a festooned pupil and tells his intern that this could block aqueous from flowing anteriorly. What is the next sequence of events that can be seen if the patient remains untreated?

choices.text: Peripheral anterior synechiae →‎‎ Iris Bombe→ Angle Closure Glaucoma
Iris Bombe ‎‎→ Peripheral anterior synechiae → Angle Closure Glaucoma
Anterior synechiae → Iris Bombe →Angle Closure Glaucoma

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Iris Bombe ‎‎→ Peripheral anterior synechiae → Angle Closure Glaucoma:

  • Iris Bombe: The forward bowing of the peripheral iris occurs due to the blockage of the flow of aqueous humor by posterior synechiae, leading to a decreased angle between the iris and cornea.

  • Peripheral Anterior Synechiae (PAS): As the iris bows forward, adhesions may form between the iris and the peripheral cornea.

  • Angle Closure Glaucoma: The combination of iris bombe and PAS can gradually close the drainage angle, leading to impaired aqueous outflow and increased risk of angle closure glaucoma.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient, Mrs. Smith, presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of gradual vision loss and occasional episodes of seeing rainbow-colored halos around lights . She  reports a family history of glaucoma. He has elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) measuring 28 mmHg in both eyes. Which of the following disc changes would not be found in this patient ?

choices.text: Slow thickening of the neuroretinal rim

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Slow thickening of the neuroretinal rim:

  • Slow thickening of the neuroretinal rim is not typically associated with glaucoma. In glaucoma, the neuroretinal rim tends to undergo thinning and notching due to optic nerve damage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- C/d ratio greater than 0.3: An increased cup-to-disc (C/D) ratio, especially if it's greater than 0.3, is often indicative of glaucomatous damage where the cup of the optic nerve becomes larger in proportion to the disc (optic nerve head).

Option B - Notching of neuroretinal rim: This would be found in glaucoma. Notching of the neuroretinal rim is a characteristic sign of glaucoma where there is localized thinning or excavation of the rim tissue.

Option C - Laminar dot sign: The lamina cribrosa is a porous opening in the sclera through which nerve fibers pass. When these nerve fibers are damaged, these openings become visible. The term "laminar dot sign" refers to the appearance of these visible openings of the lamina cribrosa due to nerve fiber damage

questions.text: A 7-year-old patient is diagnosed with a condition where one eye has reduced vision that is not correctable by glasses, reduced contrast sensitivity, and sunglass effect. In this patient, the fovea of one eye works in conjunction with the eccentric point of the other eye. What term is used to describe this phenomenon seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Abnormal retinal correspondence:

  • The clinical picture suggests of amblyopia, and the condition where the fovea of one eye works with the eccentric point of the other eye is called abnormal retinal correspondence. This can lead to visual disturbances and is an important aspect to consider during amblyopia treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Strabismic amblyopia: Strabismic amblyopia refers to the type of amblyopia caused by strabismus, which is a misalignment of the eyes and where abnormal retinal correspondence is seen. But the term specifically describing the phenomenon is abnormal retinal correspondence.

Option C - Refractive amblyopia: Refractive amblyopia is a type of amblyopia caused by significant refractive errors, such as high degrees of anisometropia or uncorrected ametropia. It does not specifically describe the phenomenon of abnormal retinal correspondence.

Option D - Meridional amblyopia: Meridional amblyopia can occur in any axis of astigmatism and is a type of refractive amblyopia. It does not specifically describe the phenomenon of abnormal retinal correspondence.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of dimunition of vision in his left eye for the past three months. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is performed, showing the findings given below.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoid macular edema :

  • The OCT examination in the above patient shows presence of cystoid spaces filled with fluid . These findings along with the presenting clinical features indicate the presence of cystoid macular edema.

CME (Cystoid Macular Edema)

Cystoid macular edema (CME) is swelling of the layers of the neurosensory retina within the macula. When excess fluid builds in the retina, it typically collects in “pockets,” referred to as “cysts.”

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Slow, painless loss of vision
  • Metamorphopsia (distortion of shape)
  • Micropsia (objects appear small and distorted) or macropsia (objects appear large and distorted)

Diagnostic Tools:

  • Amsler's grid
  • +90 D lens (best instrument to examine CME)

Investigations:

Fluorescein Angiography (FA):

  • Dye used: Fluorescein Sodium
  • Arm retina circulation time: 12 seconds
  • Pattern of leak indicates pathology
  • Limitations: invasive and may cause allergy

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):

  • Gold standard investigation for all macular disorders
  • Non-invasive
  • Provides a cross-sectional view of the retina

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Central serous retinopathy: It typically presents with serous retinal detachment and fluid accumulation underneath the neurosensory retina, often occurring in younger patients and often associated with stress or corticosteroid use.

Option C - Retinal detachment : It involves the separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium and is associated with symptoms like flashes of light and a sensation of a "curtain" coming down over the vision.

Option D - Age related macular degeneration : It is characterized by the gradual deterioration of the macula, often leading to central vision loss, but it usually presents with drusen and pigmentary changes, rather than cystic spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to a concern about inward deviation of the eyes. Upon examination, the child exhibits a varying degree of convergent squint when looking at objects up close and in the distance, and on refraction it is noticed that the patient is suffering from high hypermetropia. Which type of esotropia is most likely present in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mixed accommodative esotropia:

  • Mixed accommodative esotropia involves both high hypermetropia and an increased AC/A ratio. While high hypermetropia may contribute to the convergence squint which is the same for near and far vision, the fact that the varying squint is present for both near and distance i.e., different degrees of squint on near vision and different degrees of squint on distant vision suggests that other factors like increased AC/A ratio where the degree of squint is more for near and less for distant vision is also involved. Therefore, mixed accommodative esotropia could be a possibility in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Refractive accommodative esotropia: Refractive accommodative esotropia occurs due to uncorrected high hypermetropia, which leads to excessive accommodation and subsequent convergence squint. However, the question states that the varying degree of squint is noticeable for both near and far vision, whereas in refractive accommodative esotropia it is the same for near and far vision. Therefore, refractive accommodative esotropia is not the most likely type in this case.

Option B - Non-refractive accommodative esotropia: Non-refractive accommodative esotropia is characterized by an increased AC/A ratio, resulting in a greater squint for near vision than far vision. However, the question mentions that the patient has high hypermetropia, suggesting that the AC/A ratio is not the primary factor contributing to the child's condition. Therefore, non-refractive accommodative esotropia is not the most likely type in this case.

Option D - Non-accommodative esotropia: Non-accommodative esotropia includes various types such as stress-induced esotropia, non-seeing eyes in children within 8 years, and overcorrection exotropia. However, these conditions are not characterized by a convergent squint that is present for both near and distance vision. Therefore, non-accommodative esotropia is not the most likely type in this case.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with redness, pain, and mucopurulent discharge in the left eye. On examination, chemosis, and branched inflamed blood vessels are observed as seen in the image below. Which organism is the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
