Option C - Uncommon in chronic stages: Aschoff bodies are rarely seen in patients with chronic RHD because of the long intervals between the initial insult and the development of valve deformity. They are most often seen only in patients with acute RF.

Option D - Anitschkow cells: Aschoff bodies are indeed surrounded by Anitschkow cells, the plump activated macrophages that have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”).

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department with worsening symptoms. On examination, the patient's FEV1 is measured at 50% of the predicted value. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals a PaO2 level of 65 mmHg. Based on these findings, how would you classify the current asthma exacerbation?

choices.text: The classification cannot be determined from the provided information.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Moderate exacerbation:

  • Mild exacerbation: FEV1 > 70%, PaO2 Normal
  • Moderate exacerbation: FEV1 40-69%, PaO2 > 60 mmHg
  • Severe exacerbation: FEV1 < 40%, PaO2 > 60 mmHg

In this case, the patient's FEV1 is 50%, falling within the range for a moderate exacerbation. Additionally, the PaO2 is greater than 60 mmHg. Therefore, the classification of the current asthma exacerbation is moderate.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Other options are incorrect according to explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female was rushed to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and shortness of breath. The patient is a known case of DM type 2 but neglected medications for the past three days due to a busy schedule. Examination showed tachypnea and tachycardia. ABG analysis shows a pH of 7.28, PCO2 of 35mmHg and HCO3 of 14mEq/L. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Uncompensated metabolic acidosis:

Normal parameters of ABG-

  • pH-7.35-7.45
  • pO2-60-100
  • pCO2-35-45mmHg
  • HCO3-22-26mEq
  • Anion gap-Na-(Cl+HCO3)
  • Always look for pH ,pCO2 and HCO3 first

 

  • pH: 7.28-acidotic
  • PCO2 – 35(normal)
  • HCO3 – 14(reduced)-
  • pH is low hence this is a case of acidosis
  • PCO2 is normal. Hence a respiratory cause is unlikely.
  • HCO3 is reduced. Hence this is a case of Metabolic Acidosis
  • Since there are no compensatory CO2 changes,
  • This is an ABG of Uncompensated Metabolic Acidosis

  • Looking at the history given. This is a diabetic patient who has been off medications. The ensuing hyperglycemia can lead to Diabetic Ketoacidosis which is likely the cause of this patient's metabolic acidosis.

  • Note: DKA is more commonly associated with Type 1 DM but it can be present in severe insulin-requiring Type 2 DM as well.

questions.text: An obstetrician instructs her resident to give a PGF2 alpha injection after trying oxytocin, methylergometrine, and misoprostol to manage PPH. After a few minutes of relief, the patient starts to bleed again, so the doctor asks for a repeat dose of PGF2 alpha. Which of the following is the maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in PPH management which can be given over 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2 mg

  • IM: 0.25 mg, Every 15-30 min,
  • Maximum dose: 8 doses/24 hrs (Total 2mg).
  • Inj. Carboprost (PGF α) stimulates uterine contraction.
  • Never given via I/V route
  • Contraindication: Asthma 
  • S/E: Diarrhea 

Incorrect options:

Option A: 250 μg

Option B: 200 μg

Option D: 20 mg

questions.text: An obstetrician observed an abnormality in the placental attachment during a prenatal ultrasound examination. The image below is representative of the gross specimen of the placenta seen in that presentations. Based on this, what is the most likely placental abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Battledore placenta:

  • Battledore placenta, also known as marginal cord insertion, is a condition where the umbilical cord inserts at the margin of the placenta rather than at its center.
  • This condition is generally considered benign and is often without significant clinical implications.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Velamentous Placenta:

  • Velamentous placenta is a condition where the umbilical vessels travel within the membranes (chorionic membranes) before reaching the placenta.
  • Velamentous insertion can pose risks, especially during delivery, as the unprotected vessels are more prone to rupture.

Option C - Circumvallate placenta:

  • Circumvallate placenta is a condition where the amniotic membranes fold back around the edge of the placenta.
  • This condition can be associated with complications such as preterm birth and premature rupture of membranes.

Option D - Bilobed placenta:

  • A bilobed placenta refers to a placenta that has two distinct lobes.
  • This condition is usually a variant of normal placental development and may not have significant clinical consequences.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman undergoes routine prenatal care, including an ultrasound examination. The ultrasound reveals the presence of triplets. The obstetrician discusses the option of selective fetal reduction to improve the overall outcome of the pregnancy. In this context, what is the ideal timing and method for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 10-13 weeks with intracardiac KCL:

  • Selective fetal reduction in a triplet pregnancy is ideally performed between 10-13 weeks gestation using intracardiac KCL. This timing allows for sufficient visualization and access to the fetal hearts for the procedure
  • In multifetal pregnancy: Fetal reduction can be offered to decrease the risk of adverse events associated with multifetal pregnancy.
  • It does not affect the survival of the other twin,

Incorrect Options:

Option B: 7-9 weeks with intracardiac KCL

Option C: 10-13 weeks with intraumbilical KCL

Option D: 7-9 weeks with intraumbilical KCL

questions.text: Preeclampsia is a hypertensive disorder of pregnancy characterized by high BP, headache, visual changes and albuminuria. It requires active management to save the patient from life-threatening consequences. Which of the following is a risk factor for preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Nulliparity is a risk factor for preeclampsia.

  • Nullliparity is at an increased risk of developing preeclampsia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Thinly built

  • It is not a risk factor for preeclampsia. Increased BMI increases the risk of preeclampsia.

Option B: Multigravida

  • It decreases the risk of preeclampsia. Primigravida is at an increased risk of preeclampsia.
  • In multiparas, the incidence ranges From 2 to 5 percent.

Option D: Placenta previa

  • It does not pose an additional risk of developing preeclampsia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the emergency department at 36 weeks of gestation with spontaneous onset of labor pain. On examination, her vitals are stable, and the fetus's heart rate remains stable at 160 bpm. Further examination revealed a non-tender abdomen, and 3 contractions every 10 minutes were noted. Cervical dilatation is 6 cm. Examination findings are consistent with which stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: first stage

  • There are 4 stages of labor: first, second, third and fourth.
  • The first stage of labor starts from the onset of true labor pain to full cervical dilatation, i.e., 10cm 
  • In the above question, cervical dilatation is 6 cm which is consistent with 1st stage of labor.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Second stage 

  • This stage refers to the period from full dilatation of the cervix to delivery of the baby.

Option C: Third stage 

  • The third stage of labor begins with the delivery of the baby and ends with the delivery of the placenta and membranes. 

Option D: fourth stage 

  • The fourth stage is the observation time for 1-2 hours after delivery of the placenta

questions.text: A 22-year-old G2P1 female has a positive urine pregnancy test. On evaluation, the ultrasound reveals an adnexal mass of 2.5 x 3 cm with no intrauterine gestational sac. She is vitally stable. β-hCG titer is 1500 mIU/ml. What modality of treatment is most suitable for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • The history is suggestive of Ectopic pregnancy
  • Given the stable condition of the patient and the relatively low β-hCG titer, medical management with methotrexate is a suitable option. Methotrexate is often used in the management of unruptured ectopic pregnancies, and it works by inhibiting cell division.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Progesterone therapy is given for intrauterine pregnancy requiring pregnancy support in cases like recurrent pregnancy losses, vaginal bleeding, etc.

Option C: Laparoscopic surgery may be required where surgical management is indicated or where the diagnosis is not clear.

Option D: Laparotomy is usually done for ruptured ectopic where a patient is hemodynamically unstable.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient has come to the hospital complaining of a history of multiple abortions. She had 3 spontaneous miscarriages in the second trimester, and the episode occurred 1 month back. She tests positive for LAC (lupus anticoagulant) and ACL (anticardiolipin antibody). Which of the following pharmacotherapy is most appropriate for this patient in her subsequent pregnancies?

choices.text: Aspirin + Low molecular weight heparin + Prednisolone

questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • A positive test for LAC (lupus anticoagulant) and ACL (anticardiolipin antibody) is suggestive of APLA syndrome: D/t presence of Antiphospholipid antibodies (LAC, ACA, beta GP1 antibodies).
  • It is an autoimmune disorder associated with 2nd trimester RPL.
  • DOC for APLA in non-pregnant women - Warfarin (Teratogenic)
  • DOC for APLA in Pregnancy - Low-dose aspirin (50mg/day) and heparin (5000 units S/C twice daily) for up to 34 weeks. UFH & LMWH are equally effective and safe
  • Combining aspirin with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is a common approach in the management of recurrent pregnancy loss associated with antiphospholipid antibodies. LMWH has anticoagulant properties and is often used in addition to aspirin to reduce the risk of thrombosis and improve pregnancy outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • Aspirin has antiplatelet effects and may be used in some cases to prevent complications related to blood clotting. However, in the context of positive lupus anticoagulant (LAC) and anticardiolipin antibody (ACL) in a woman with a history of recurrent miscarriages, aspirin alone may not be sufficient.

Option C:

  • Prednisolone is not used for the treatment of APLA

Option D:

  • Prednisolone is not used for the treatment of APLA. Progesterone can be given for pregnancy support and to maintain uterine quiescence. However, aspirin and LMWH have to be given

questions.text: The CTG shown in the image below may be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • The given CTG shows variable deceleration which is seen in umbilical cord compression.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • Head compression is seen in early deceleration

Option C:

  • Fetal hypoxia is seen in late deceleration

Option D: Normal

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman G4P3L3 presents at full-term pregnancy with labour pains. On examination, she has a third-degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following complications can be expected during her labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Postpartum hemorrhage

  • Postpartum hemorrhage is a significant risk in this scenario. Uterine prolapse can interfere with the normal contractility of the uterus, leading to ineffective uterine contractions and an increased risk of excessive bleeding during and after labor.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Precipitous labor

  • Precipitous labor refers to extremely rapid labor and delivery, sometimes associated with uterine prolapse. However, this option is less likely because uterine prolapse typically results in slowed labor progress due to the malposition of the uterus.

Option C: Cervical dystocia

  • Cervical dystocia, also known as cervical failure to dilate, can occur independently of uterine prolapse. Uterine prolapse itself is more likely to affect the descent of the fetal head and the progression of labor rather than causing cervical dystocia.

Option D: Intrauterine death

  • While uterine prolapse is a concerning condition, it does not necessarily lead to intrauterine fetal demise. However, the prolapse can potentially compromise fetal well-being during labor due to impaired uterine blood flow or umbilical cord compression. Prompt medical intervention and possibly a cesarean section may be necessary to minimize such risks.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a gynecological OPD with a history of 7 weeks of amenorrhea and slight vaginal spotting. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. The crown-rump length (CRL) is 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac with a calculated gestational age of 5+6 weeks on transvaginal sonography (TVS). However, the cardiac activity could not be seen. What of the following would be the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform an immediate dilation and curettage (D&C)

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Repeat TVS in one week

  • In cases of uncertain viability where no cardiac activity is seen on ultrasound, it is advisable to wait and repeat the transvaginal sonography (TVS) after a week to confirm the absence of fetal cardiac activity. This interval allows for a more accurate assessment of the pregnancy status and helps avoid unnecessary interventions.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Perform an immediate dilation and curettage (D&C)

  • Dilation and curettage (D&C) is a surgical procedure that involves dilating the cervix and scraping the uterine lining to remove the contents. In cases where there is uncertainty about the viability of the pregnancy, an immediate D&C is generally not recommended. It is important to confirm the absence of fetal cardiac activity through a repeat ultrasound before considering such an invasive procedure.

Option C: Prescribe progesterone supplementation

  • Progesterone supplementation is typically used in cases of threatened miscarriage or in women with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss. However, in the scenario described, the absence of fetal cardiac activity suggests a potential nonviable pregnancy. Progesterone supplementation is unlikely to impact the outcome in such cases, and it may not be the most appropriate intervention.

Option D: Serum hCG levels

  • Serum HCG levels are more useful till the gestational sac is not visualized, to determine whether pregnancy is intrauterine or ectopic. However, in this case, falling serial HCG levels may suggest a failing pregnancy but confirmation would be made only after non-visualization of heart beat after a week.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman came to OPD with a distended abdomen and postmenopausal bleeding. Imaging suggests bilateral ovarian complex masses with a CA 125 value of 1500. A comprehensive surgical staging is planned. Pre operatively, bilateral ovarian masses are seen with surface involvement and ascites. There is no pelvic or extrapelvic extension of tumor or lymph node involvement. What is the appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Proceed with surgical staging with hysterectomy + bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy
Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy followed by adjuvant chemoradiation.

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C- Proceed with surgical staging with hysterectomy + bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy:

The diagnosis here is Stage 1C ovarian cancer, according to FIGO staging

  • The tumor is limited to one or both ovaries, with any of the following.
    • The ovary capsule is ruptured
    • The tumor is detected on the ovary surface
    • Positive malignant cells are detected in the ascites or peritoneal washings
  • Treatment of Stage 1C (HIGH-RISK STAGE 1 Disease) is adjuvant chemotherapy following Comprehensive surgical staging (involves hysterectomy + BSO)

  • Management of ovarian cancer:

    EARLY Low-risk Stage 1A, 1B, low-grade Surgical staging
      High-risk Stage 1C, high-grade Surgical staging + adjuvant chemotherapy
    ADVANCED   Stage II, III, IV Maximal cytoreduction + adjuvant chemotherapy

    STEPS OF COMPREHENSIVE SURGICAL STAGING

  • Vertical midline incision
  • Ascitic fluid for cytology
  • If no ascites: take peritoneal washings
  • Biopsy of suspicious lesions and diaphragm
  • Supracolic omentectomy
  • Retroperitoneal lymph node evaluation

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Maximal cytoreduction surgery:

  • Maximal cytoreduction surgery is required for stages II, III, IV

Option B- Hysterectomy + bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy:

  • Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is insufficient surgery for ovarian cancer, and a comprehensive surgical staging along with adjuvant chemotherapy should instead be done

Option D- Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy followed by adjuvant chemoradiation.:

  • Hysterectomy must be done on all cases of ovarian epithelial cancers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of lower back pain and cyclical dysmenorrhea for the last 12 months. She has been married for the last 4 years and has never conceived. She is referred to the infertility clinic for further evaluation. The patient has regular cycles with dysmenorrhea. Further investigations revealed dark red to bluish vesicles surrounded by flame-like lesions on the peritoneum. Which of the following is the most common site for a lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Ovary

  • Ovaries are a common site of endometriosis involvement.
  • Ovarian endometriomas, also known as chocolate cysts, can form, leading to cystic masses filled with endometrial tissue.

Sites of Predilection

  • The most common site is the ovary
  • The second most common site is Pouch of Douglas
  • Bowel
  • Lung [periodic hemoptysis] (Vicarious Menstruation)
  • Nose [Periodic epistaxis] (Vicarious Menstruation)
  • Eyes (periodic subconjunctival hemorrhage] (Vicarious Menstruation)

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Fallopian tube

  • It is also a site for endometriosis. However, the more common site is the ovary.
  • Endometriosis in the fallopian tubes may lead to inflammation, scarring, and potential obstruction, impacting fertility.

Option B: Cervix

  • While endometriosis can affect the uterus, it is not the most common site.
  • Endometriosis in the uterus may involve the outer layer (adenomyosis) or other structures, but ovarian involvement is more prevalent.

Option D: Pouch of Douglas

  • The Pouch of Douglas, also known as the rectouterine pouch or cul-de-sac, is the space between the rectum and the back wall of the uterus.
  • It is the 2nd most common site for endometriosis.
  • Endometriosis can involve the Pouch of Douglas, causing pain and adhesions in this area.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female, P1L1, underwent a routine pap smear, which was reported as CIN III (High-Grade Squamous Intraepithelial Lesion/ HSIL). The colposcopy showed an area of abnormal cells around her cervix. What will be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Colposcopy biopsy

  • A colposcopy is recommended if cervical screening finds cell HPV-induced cell changes.
  • These dysplastic cells can turn into cervical cancer cells.
  • Colposcopy is a procedure that examines the cervix for abnormal tissue and takes a biopsy if needed.
  • If CIN III is found, the next step is a colposcopy-directed biopsy for tissue diagnosis and to plan further management

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Trachelectomy

  • Surgical removal of the cervix, is called trachelectomy.
  • Trachelectomy is done in younger women with early cervix cancer (with a tumor no larger than 2-3 centimeters).
  • Trachelectomy need not be done in premalignant lesions in a young female unless a biopsy proves invasive carcinoma.

Option B: Hysterectomy

  • A hysterectomy is not done for CIN III unless a biopsy proves cancer

Option C: Conization

  • Conization of the cervix is defined as the excision of a cone-shaped or cylindrical wedge from the cervix uteri that includes the transformation zone and all or a portion of the endocervical canal.
  • Conization is not done in a young patient with an incomplete family as it causes
    • Short cervix→ cervical incompetence → abortions
    • Stenosis→ Infertility

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, P1L1,  presents to the physician complaining of heavy menstrual bleeding with cycles lasting 7-10 days with heavy flow and passage of clots. She has not responded to oral tranexamic acid. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following treatment options is least preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Danazol

  • Danazol is a synthetic androgen that suppresses ovarian function and decreases estrogen production. It reduces menstrual blood loss by inducing a hypoestrogenic state.
  • While Danazol can be effective in reducing menstrual bleeding, it is the least preferred option due to its significant side effects, including weight gain, acne, hirsutism, and potential long-term effects like liver toxicity and lipid profile changes. These side effects limit its use compared to other more tolerable and equally effective options.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Combined OCP

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills contain estrogen and progesterone, which help to regulate menstrual cycles and reduce menstrual blood loss.
  • They are a common and effective treatment for heavy menstrual bleeding and are often preferred due to their dual role in providing contraception and regulating cycles.

Option B: Cyclical progesterone

  • Progesterone helps to stabilize the endometrial lining and reduce menstrual bleeding. It is typically given in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.
  • Cyclical progesterone is effective in managing heavy menstrual bleeding, especially in women who cannot take estrogen.

Option C: LNG IUD (The levonorgestrel intrauterine device )

  • The LNG IUD releases levonorgestrel locally in the uterus, which thins the endometrial lining and significantly reduces menstrual blood loss.
  • It is highly effective in treating heavy menstrual bleeding and provides long-term relief and contraception.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to gynecology OPD in an anxious state, reporting early pregnancy loss 1 day back. She reports spontaneous abortion in the 5th week of her pregnancy. She has been married for 5 months. Her HSG reveals two separate cavities of the uterus, cervix and vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Uterus didelphys

  • Uterus didelphys is a complete failure of fusion of Mullerian duct resulting in two uteri, cervix, and vagina.
  • It can lead to pregnancy complications and dysmenorrhea. Few patients may have surgery to treat uterus didelphys, but most cases don't require it.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Bicornuate uterus

  • It is described as a heart-shaped uterus, having two sides instead of one hollow cavity.
  • The cervix and vagina are single

Option C: Subseptate uterus

  • It is a mild form of congenital anomaly in which a half septum is present within the uterus, not infringing on the cervix.

Option D: Unicornuate Uterus

  • A unicornuate uterus is a rare disorder that causes a female to have only half a uterus.

questions.text: After engaging in unprotected intercourse 5 hours ago, a 28-year-old woman is brought to the gynecology outpatient department by her partner seeking advice. She took a tablet of levonorgestrel 0.75mg because she does not want to become pregnant. Given the situation, what is the appropriate next dosage of the medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: 1 tablet (0.75mg) after 12 hours

  • As the first dose is taken another tablet should be taken after 12 hours

  • Levonorgestrel (E. Pills) 0.75 mg, two doses given at 12-hour intervals, is very successful and without any side effects. The two tablets (1.50 mg) can be taken as a single dose also. The first dose should be taken within 72 hours

  • 0.75 mg stat and after 12 hours

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 1 tab after 24 hours

Option C: 2 tabs after 12 hours

Option D: 2 tabs after 24 hours

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with upper abdominal pain. She had been previously diagnosed and treated for recurrent purulent vaginal discharge. Diagnostic laparoscopy revealed the following image. Which of the following statements is inappropriate regarding this patient?

choices.text: It may lpresent with right upper quadrant pain
The pain may refer to the shoulder or upper arm
It is most commonly associated with tubercular salpingitis

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Most commonly associated with tubercular salpingitis

  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is most commonly associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by sexually transmitted infections such as Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, rather than tubercular salpingitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: May lead to right upper quadrant pain

  • The pain in Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is localized in the right upper quadrant because the liver is involved due to the formation of violin string-like fibrous bands.
  • That is why it is also called perihepatitis.

Option B: Pain may refer to the shoulder or upper arm

  • The upper abdominal pain caused by perihepatitis (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome) may refer to the shoulder or upper arm.

Option D: Pain resembles cholecystitis

  • The pain in Fitz-Hugh-Curtis is localized in the right upper quadrant resembling the pain of cholecystitis.
  • That is why cholecystitis is also a differential for Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

questions.text: A woman at 48 years of age presents with the absence of menses for one year. The patient was vitally stable on examination, and her abdominopelvic assessment wasunremarkable. The patient was not using any medication and was not on any illicit drugs. Her pregnancy test is negative. On laboratory evaluation, her FSH level is 45 IU/mL. Which out of these is the most likely cause of this condition?

choices.text: Ovarian failure secondary to cessation of pituitary secretion of gonadotropins
Ovarian failure secondary to the cessation of pituitary secretion of gonadotropins
Ovarian failure due to follicular exhaustion

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Ovarian failure due to follicular exhaustion

  • Menopause occurs due to Ovarian failure due to programmed apoptosis of ovarian follicles.
  • Please note: The HPO axis remains intact even in older women. Because of its integrity, there is an increase in FSH due to the loss of estrogens’ inhibitory feedback on the pituitary.
  • Due to exhaustion of ovarian function after menopause, estrogen levels decline. As a result of low estrogen, the feedback inhibition of gonadotropins is lost, thus increasing levels of FSH and LH.
  • FSH > 10 is suggestive of menopause
  • FSH > 40 is diagnostic of menopause

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Ovarian failure secondary to the cessation of pituitary secretion of gonadotropins

  • The HPO axis remains intact even in older women. Because of the integrity of this axis, there is an increase in FSH due to the loss of inhibitory feedback of estrogens on the pituitary.

Option B: Ovarian failure secondary to the cessation of hypothalamic secretion of GnRH

  • Due to exhaustion of ovarian function after menopause, estrogen levels decline. As a result of low estrogen, the feedback inhibition of gonadotropins is lost, thus increasing levels of FSH and LH. The presentation, in this case, is of primary ovarian failure, not secondary.

Option C: Deranged hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis functioning

  • The HPO axis remains intact even in older women, and because of the integrity of this axis, there is an increase in FSH due to the loss of inhibitory feedback of estrogens on the pituitary

questions.text: A 34-year-old female complained of involuntary urine leakage occurring 3 weeks after a vaginal delivery assisted with forceps. She reports constant dribbling of urine regardless of position or activity, with minimal urine output during voiding. She is multiparous P4+1. Which of the following is the best test to reach a diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Cystoscopy

  • History suggests a vesicovaginal fistula following obstetrical trauma due to the application of forceps.
  • A vesicovaginal fistula is an abnormal opening between the bladder and the wall of the vagina, resulting in urine leakage out of the vagina.
  • Tests done to diagnose vesicovaginal fistula are
    • Clinical examination for the fistula site and type of leak, including three swab tests: methylene blue dye test.
    • Cystoscopy.
    • Cystography.
    • VCUG: voiding cystourethrography.
    • CT, urine c/s, IVP, and USG Retrograde pyelography may be done to rule out other causes of urine incontinence.
  • The best investigation for vesicovaginal fistula is cystoscopy.
    • Cystoscopy tells about
      • Site of fistula
      • Size of fistula
      • No. of fistula
      • Ureteric opening

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Three swab test

  • Three swab test is a clinical examination to rule out the kind of fistula. It does not provide a definite diagnosis like a cystoscopy.

Option C: Urine culture

  • Urine culture has no role in the diagnosis of vesicovaginal fistula. It is done to rule out infections of the bladder.

Option D: Intravenous pyelogram

  • An intravenous pyelogram can be used to diagnose fistulas but cystoscopy is still more sensitive

questions.text: Histopathology of staging laparotomy done for carcinoma endometrium reveals more than 50% myometrium invasion with vaginal involvement, parametrial involvement but no pelvic and para-aortic lymph node involvement. What is the Stage of Ca Endometrium ?
questions.solution:
Option A: III B

  • Vaginal and parametrial involvement is stage IIIB of Ca endometrium without lymph node involvement.

FIGO staging system for Ca Endometrium
Stage Ia

Tumor contained to the corpus uteri

IA No or less than half myometrial invasion

IB Invasion equal to or more than half of the myometrium
Stage II Tumor invades the cervical stroma but does not extend beyond the uterusb
Stage IIIa

Local and /or regional spread of tumorc

III A Tumor invades the serosa of the corpus uteri and/or adnexas

III B Vaginal and/or parametrial involvement

III C Metastases to pelvis and/or para-aortic lymph nodes

III C1 Positive pelvic nodes

III C2 Positive para-aortic lymph nodes with/ without positive pelvic lymph nodes
Stage IVa

Tumor invades bladder and/or bowel mucosa and/or distant metastases

IVA Tumor invasion of bladder and/or bowel mucosa

IVB Distant metastases, including intra-abdominal metastases and or inguinal lymph nodes

 

  • aInclude grades 1,2, or 3
  • bEndocervical glandular involvement only should be considered as stage I and no longer as stage II.
  • cPositive cytology has to be reported separately without changing the stage.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: IIIA

  • Tumor invades the serosa of the corpus uteri and/or adnexas, and no parametrial involvement is yet present.

Option C: III C1

  • Tumor invasion along with positive pelvic nodes.

Option D: III C2

  • Positive para-aortic lymph nodes with or without positive pelvic lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding incidence and prevalence?

choices.text: Prevalence is independent of duration of disease
Incidence indicates the probability of developing a disease
Prevalence is calculated from a cross-sectional study
Incidence includes new cases of a disease only

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prevalence is independent of duration of disease:

  • Prevalence is dependent on the duration of a disease.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Average duration of disease

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Incidence indicates the probability of developing a disease: Incidence indicates the probability of developing a disease, whereas prevalence indicates the chances of already having a disease.

Option C - Prevalence is calculated from a cross-sectional study: Prevalence is calculated from a cross-sectional study, and the incidence is calculated from a cohort study.

Option D - Incidence includes new cases of a disease only: Incidence includes new cases of a disease only, whereas prevalence includes both old and new cases.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases follow the iceberg phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tuberculosis:

  • Tuberculosis (TB) is a disease that exemplifies the iceberg phenomenon because many cases of TB go undiagnosed or unreported, especially in regions with limited access to healthcare or diagnostic resources. TB can remain latent in individuals for years before becoming active, making it difficult to detect and treat. Therefore, the true extent of TB cases often goes unrecognized, with only a fraction of cases being reported or diagnosed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Measles: Measles is a highly contagious viral infection that does not follow the iceberg phenomenon because most cases are readily diagnosed and reported.

Option B - Tetanus: Tetanus does not follow the iceberg phenomenon because most cases are readily diagnosed and reported.

Option D - Rabies: Rabies is a viral infection that does not follow the iceberg phenomenon because most cases are readily diagnosed and reported.

questions.text: Which level of prevention focuses on reducing the prevalence of a disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Secondary Prevention:

  • Action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.
    • Secondary prevention focuses on reducing the prevalence of a disease by detecting and treating it at an early stage before complications develop.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primordial Prevention: Primordial prevention aims to prevent the emergence and development of risk factors for diseases in populations or communities.

Option B - Primary Prevention: Primary prevention aims to prevent the occurrence of a disease, so it focuses on the incidence of the disease.

Option D - Tertiary prevention: Tertiary prevention focuses on reducing the impact of a disease that has already occurred by preventing complications, disabilities, and further deterioration of health.

questions.text: A group of officials from the Public Health Department of a renowned institute conducted a filarial survey in a village with poor sanitation. For the mass blood survey, they performed the DEC (Diethylcarbamazine) provocation test on several individuals from the village. What is the correct dose of DEC administered in this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 100 mg:

  • Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, or Brugia timori, and is treated with diethylcarbamazine (DEC).
  • DEC provocation tests are used to diagnose latent infections and are also part of mass filarial surveys.
  • In a DEC provocation test, the microfilariae (Mf) can be induced to appear in the peripheral blood in the daytime by administrating 100 mg of diethylcarbamazine orally.
  • Mf begin to reach their peak within 15 minutes and begin to decline 2 hours later.
  • The blood can be examined one hour after administering the DEC.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- 150 mg:

  • This dose is higher than the typical dose used for the DEC provocation test and may lead to an exaggerated response, potentially increasing the risk of adverse effects such as fever, headache, and malaise.

Option C- 200 mg:

  • A dose of 200 mg is higher than the standard dose and may not offer additional benefit in terms of test accuracy.
  • It also increases the risk of adverse reactions.

Option D- 50 mg:

  • This dose is lower than the standard dose and may not provide sufficient stimulation to assess the viability of microfilariae effectively.
  • It could potentially lead to false-negative results.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman came to the clinic for a consultation regarding contraception. She expressed interest in starting oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and requests information about the contents of a particular brand she saw advertised. The physician provided her with a package inserted in the image below. Based on the information provided, what is the composition of the oral contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and ethinylestradiol 0.03 mg:

  • The composition of the oral contraceptive depicted in the image is Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and Ethinylestradiol 0.03 mg.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D provide compositions that do not match the package insert shown in the image.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the community health center for routine immunization. The parents inquire about the correct dose of the Rotavirus vaccine being administered under the National Immunization Schedule (NIS). Which of the following is the correct dose of the Rotavirus vaccine given under NIS?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5 drops:

  • Rotavirus vaccination is crucial in preventing severe diarrhea, particularly in infants and young children.
  • Adhering to the recommended dosage ensures optimal protection against Rotavirus infection and its associated complications.
  • As per the National Immunization Schedule, a total of three doses of the Rotavirus vaccine is recommended (can be given till one year of age).
    • 6 weeks
    • 10 weeks
    • 14 weeks
  • The recommended dose is 5 drops (oral).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D:

  • These do not indicate the correct dosage of the Rotavirus vaccine

questions.text: In a municipal corporation, there has been a surge in biomedical waste generated due to the recent opening of a hospital in the vicinity. To efficiently manage this waste and prevent environmental pollution, the authorities decide to implement a dual chamber incinerator. Which among the following is the temperature range used in the Dual Chamber Incinerator?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 800-1100°C:

  • The optimal temperature range for the primary combustion chamber of a dual chamber incinerator is 800-1100°C, ensuring thorough destruction of biomedical waste and minimizing environmental and public health risks.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not applicable as they do not provide the correct temperature range for the dual chamber incinerator.

questions.text: All are the characteristics of Shallow Well except

choices.text: Taps water from above the first impervious layer

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Very hard water:

  • This is not a characteristic of Shallow well
  • Very hard water is found in deep wells whereas shallow well has moderately hard water.

questions.text: Which among the following is the region where vaccination, according to the Essen regimen, is given in adults ?

choices.text: The anterolateral aspect of the thigh

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Deltoid region:

  • The region where vaccination according to the Essen regimen is given is the Deltoid

Essen regimen

  • It is an intramuscular regimen
  • Schedule dose: On days 0, 3, 7, 14, 28 total 5 visits.
  • It is given on one site only.
  • Hence, it is 1-1-1-1-1.

Site:

  • For adults, it is given on the deltoid region.
  • For children, the Anterolateral aspect of the thigh.
  • Dose: 0.5ml; one complete vial is used.
  • It is not cost-effective.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D:

  • These are not the regions where the Essen regimen is given

questions.text: All of the following United Nations organizations have their headquarters in New York, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – UNAIDS:

  • UNAIDS (Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS) is not headquartered in New York.
  • Its main office is in Geneva, Switzerland.
  • UNAIDS coordinates the global response to HIV/AIDS, working to end the epidemic as a public health threat.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - UNDP:

  • The headquarters of UNDP (United Nations Development Programme) is located in New York, USA. UNDP focuses on eradicating poverty, reducing inequalities, and promoting sustainable development worldwide.

Option B - UNICEF:

  • UNICEF's (United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund) headquarters is indeed situated in New York, USA. UNICEF works to provide humanitarian and developmental assistance to children and mothers in developing countries.

Option C – UNFPA:

  • UNFPA (United Nations Population Fund) is headquartered in New York, USA. It aims to deliver a world where every pregnancy is wanted, every childbirth is safe, and every young person's potential is fulfilled.

questions.text: Which study design is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cross-over trial:

  • The study design layout involves participants progressing through trial phases, receiving multiple interventions in sequence with a washout period to minimize carryover effects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Concurrent parallel trial:

  • Two randomly assigned study and control groups are compared. Study subjects remain in the same group (study or control group) for the total duration of the investigation

Option C - Two-by-two factorial design:

  • The subjects are first randomized to treatment arm A or B to address one hypothesis and thereafter within each group, there is further randomization to treatments X or Y for evaluation of the second hypothesis.

Option D - Two-by-two-by-two factorial design:

  • It is an extension of the two-by-two study design in which each subgroup is further randomized into two more groups.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the community health center by his parents. On examination, the child presents with thinning of hair, skin changes, and a distended abdomen. Laboratory investigations reveal hypoalbuminemia. The child is subsequently diagnosed with Kwashiorkar. Which of the following characteristics is not typically associated with Kwashiorkor?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Ribs are prominent:

  • Kwashiorkor is a form of severe malnutrition caused by protein deficiency.
  • The most commonly affected age group is children 6 months to 3 years.
  • Prominent ribs are not typically associated with Kwashiorkor.
  • Instead, in severe cases of malnutrition such as marasmus, where there is significant muscle wasting and loss of subcutaneous fat, ribs may become prominent due to the lack of tissue covering.

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus

  • More severe

  • Children with protein deficiency only

  • Age: 6 months to 3 years

  • Presence of subcutaneous fat

  • Edema is present

  • Presence of enlarged fatty liver

  • Ribs are not prominent

  • Lethargic

  • Mild or no muscle wasting

  • Poor appetite

  • Requires adequate proteins

  • More hair changes

  • Flaky paint like skin

  • Moon appearance

  • More common

  • Children with both protein and calorie deficiency

  • Age: from infants to less than one year

  • No subcutaneous fat

  • Edema is absent

  • No fatty liver

  • Ribs are prominent

  • Alert and irritable

  • Severe muscle wasting

  • Voracious feeder

  • Requires adequate fats, proteins and carbohydrates

  • Less hair changes

  • Wrinkled, dry face

  • Wise old man appearance

Incorrect options:

Option A - Presence of subcutaneous fat:

  • In Kwashiorkor, there is often the presence of subcutaneous fat, giving the child a swollen appearance despite being malnourished.
  • This is due to the imbalance in protein and carbohydrate intake, leading to the accumulation of adipose tissue.

Option B - Edema is present:

  • Edema, particularly bilateral pitting edema, is a hallmark feature of Kwashiorkor.
  • It occurs due to decreased oncotic pressure resulting from hypoalbuminemia, leading to fluid retention in the interstitial spaces.

Option C - Presence of enlarged fatty liver:

  • In Kwashiorkor, there is often hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of fat in the liver, leading to fatty liver.
  • This occurs as a consequence of altered lipid metabolism in malnutrition.

questions.text: Three suspected cases of acute flaccid paralysis have been reported in a village in the state of Bihar. The epidemiologist decides to carry out a stool test in the reported cases to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is true regarding the process used for this investigation?

choices.text: Red carriers carry reverse cold chain products.
The temperature required to carry the stool sample is 0°C.
The carrier can be transported to the National Institute of Virology in Pune within 48 hours.
Blue carriers carry reverse cold chain products.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Red carriers carry reverse cold chain products:

  • Reverse Cold Chain is used to carry stool samples from suspected cases of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP). 
  • The temperature required to carry the stool sample is +2°C to +8°C.
  • This carrier can be transported to the National Institute of Virology in Pune within 72 hours.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- The temperature required to carry the stool sample is 0°C.

  • This is incorrect. The temperature required to carry the stool sample is between +2°C to +8°C.

Option C- The carrier can be transported to the National Institute of Virology in Pune within 48 hours.

  • This is incorrect. The carrier can be transported to the National Institute of Virology in Pune within 72 hours.

Option D- Blue carriers carry reverse cold chain products.

  • This is incorrect. Red carriers, not blue carriers, are used to carry reverse cold chain products.

questions.text: A woman 5 months postpartum comes to gynecology OPD for starting contraception. She wants the one which won’t need regular pills intake or memorisation. She has a history of latex allergy and menorrhagia. Which of the following will be an ideal contraceptive for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- DMPA:

  • Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (also known as DepoProvera) is now available under the name of ANTARA (a newer contraceptive that has now been introduced under National family welfare programs & is freely available till the level of sub-center).
  • Dose - 150 mg IM for 3 months
  • Advantages:
    • Highly effective
    • Long-lasting and reversible
    • Can be used during lactation because it has progesterone and no estrogen.
  • Adverse effects may include irregularities in menstrual cycles.
  • This would be a good choice for this woman as it can be used during lactation because it has progesterone and no estrogen. Since it is an injectable hormonal contraceptive, it can be prescribed in this patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- IUD:

  • This patient has menorrhagia, hence IUDs should not be given.

Option B- OCPs:

  • This patient has maintained that she doesn’t want to take pills.
  • Hence OCP’s should not be given.

Option D- CONDOM:

  • This patient has latex allergy, condom is contraindicated in this patient.

questions.text: All are the correct characteristics of the p-value, except?

choices.text: p-value is the probability of committing a Type 2 error
It tells how many times one can reject the true null hypothesis–H0
The max threshold for committing a Type 1 error is set at 5% known as the α level of significance
p-value has to be less than α, (p <0.05) when the p-value is less than α the result is statistically significant

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - p-value is the probability of committing a Type 2 error:

  • This statement is incorrect.
  • The p-value is not the probability of committing a Type 2 error.
  • Instead, it is the probability of obtaining the observed data, or more extreme results, under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true.
  • p-value is the probability of committing a Type 1 error.
  • Type 2 error refers to failing to reject a false null hypothesis, and its probability is denoted by β, not the p-value.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It tells how many times one can reject the true null hypothesis–H0:

  • This statement is correct.
  • The p-value indicates the strength of evidence against the null hypothesis.
  • A lower p-value suggests stronger evidence against the null hypothesis, leading to the rejection of the null hypothesis in favor of the alternative hypothesis.

Option C - The maximum threshold for committing a Type 1 error is set at 5% known as the α level of significance:

  • This statement is correct.
  • In hypothesis testing, the significance level (α) is predetermined and represents the maximum probability of committing a Type 1 error, which is the rejection of a true null hypothesis.
  • The conventional value for α is often set at 0.05, indicating a 5% chance of incorrectly rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true.

Option D - P-value has to be less than α (p < 0.05). When the p-value is less than α, the result is statistically significant:

  • This statement is correct.
  • In hypothesis testing, if the p-value is less than the predetermined significance level (α), typically 0.05, the result is considered statistically significant.
  • It suggests that the observed data are unlikely to have occurred under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true, leading to the rejection of the null hypothesis.

questions.text: Which among the following is the current infant mortality rate which is given by the Sample registration system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 28/1000:

  • The current infant mortality rate, which is given by the Sample registration system, is 28/1000.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, D: These do not match the current infant mortality rates that are given by the Sample registration system

questions.text: As part of a school health screening program, questionnaires are distributed to the children. The questionnaire is about the types of food the children consume on a daily basis. They are required to have the questionnaires filled out by their parents. After the screening program is concluded, an analysis shows that most of the children’s diets consist of polished rice and lack diversity in fruits and vegetables. The rice shown in the image is rich in which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vitamin A:

  • The image shows “golden rice.”
  • Golden rice is a genetically modified variety of rice (Oryza sativa) that has been engineered to produce beta-carotene, a precursor of vitamin A, in the edible parts of the grain.
  • This modification is aimed at addressing vitamin A deficiency, which is a significant public health issue, particularly in regions where rice is a staple food and access to a diverse diet is limited.
  • Beta-carotene is converted to vitamin A in the human body, and adequate vitamin A intake is essential for maintaining vision, immune function, and overall health.
  • The nutritional content of golden rice is similar to that of conventional rice, with the added benefit of beta-carotene.
  • However, it is important to note that golden rice is not intended to replace a varied and balanced diet but rather to complement existing efforts to combat vitamin A deficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vitamin D:

  • Golden rice is not rich in Vitamin D.
  • Halibut fish, liver oil and cod fish are the richest sources of vitamin D.

Option B - Vitamin C:

  • Golden rice is not rich in Vitamin C.
  • Amla or Indian Gooseberry and Guava are the richest sources of Vitamin C.

Option D - Vitamin K:

  • Golden rice is not rich in Vitamin K.
  • Green leafy vegetables are rich sources of vitamin K.

questions.text: In a municipal swimming pool, proper chlorination is essential to maintain water hygiene and prevent the spread of waterborne diseases. The pool manager decides to use bleaching powder for chlorination. While preparing the solution, the manager wonders about the amount of chlorine released from 100 grams of bleaching powder. Which of the following options represents the correct amount of chlorine released?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 33 grams:

  • Bleaching powder, or chlorinated lime (CaOCl2) is a white amorphous powder with a pungent smell of chlorine. It releases chlorine gas when dissolved in water.
  • When freshly made it contains about 33 percent of “available chlorine.”
  • The amount of chlorine released from 100 grams of bleaching is 33 grams.
  • The principle of chlorination is to ensure a free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/L at the end of one hour of contact.
  • Highly polluted and turbid waters are not suitable for direct chlorination.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are not the correct amounts of chlorine released from 100 grams of bleaching powder.

questions.text: A local health department in a village is investigating an outbreak of vector-borne diseases. Several patients have presented with symptoms, including high fever, severe joint pain, and rash. The health authorities suspect the involvement of Aedes mosquitoes,  infamous vectors for transmitting various diseases. Among the listed diseases below, which is NOT caused by the Aedes mosquito?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - West Nile fever:

  • Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti, are responsible for transmitting several diseases. 
  • Dengue fever, Chikungunya, and Yellow fever are all transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. 
  • Aedes is NOT a vector for West Nile virus. This virus is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes.
  • The clinical picture shows that the patients in a rural area presented with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, joint pain, and a rash.
  • Further history and lab investigations are required to comment on the diagnosis.
  • Mosquito control measures should be initiated when an outbreak is recognized.
  • Common methods include:
    • Environmental sanitation
    • Larvicides
    • Biological control using aquatic predators
    • Chemical control using spraying methods
Diseases transmitted by mosquitoes
Anopheles Malaria
Culex Japanese encephalitis, Filariasis, West Nile fever
Aedes Dengue, Chikungunya, Rift Valley fever, Zika virus
Mansonia Brugian filariasis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dengue Fever:

  • Dengue fever is caused by dengue virus, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
  • DF manifests as fever with a headache, retro-orbital pain, arthralgia, and myalgia.
  • It can progress to more severe forms - dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome.

Option B - Zika: 

  • Zika virus is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. 
  • Most infected patients are asymptomatic.
  • Others present with a maculopapular rash and arthralgia.

Option D - Rift Valley Fever:

  • Rift Valley fever is a viral zoonotic disease that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. 
  • It is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and blood-feeding flies. 
  • In humans, the disease ranges from a mild flu-like illness to severe hemorrhagic fever that can be fatal.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is contraindicated in a person with egg allergy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  A - Yellow fever vaccine:

  • Yellow fever and influenza vaccines are indeed contraindicated in individuals with an egg allergy. These vaccines contain residual egg protein, making them unsuitable for those with egg allergies.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - DPT vaccine:

  • Contraindicated in Progressive neurologic disease.
  • DPT can be given to people who have convulsions controlled by anti-Epileptics.

Option C - MMR:

  • During disasters and epidemics, health professionals are not given measels component of MMR.

Option D - Varicella vaccine:

  • It is contraindicated during pregnancy.

Options B, C, D: These do not indicate the vaccines contraindicated in a person with an egg allergy.
